entry.title: The End of Poverty?
entry.content:
Over the weekend I watched "The End of Poverty." This film has been in just about all of the previews of other new documentaries that I've watched so I thought it had to be a good one. The preview (see below) does grab your attention, but after watching it, I have mixed feelings about it.

We all know that poverty exists and there are some individual choices we can make to help those in need, but I don't see how we can completely reorganize our entire country to help poorer countries. Would the sum of all individuals make a collective decision to consume less and conserve more energy? That seems to be the rhetorical question that the film is asking. The answer lies with us.

entry.title: Justified (2010)
entry.content:
There are few actors who can effectively pull off a cowboy hat anymore. Perhaps this has contributed to the relative death of the western, which is sad because I enjoy a good western. Every once in a while we'll get a True Grit or The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford, but more often than not what we get is in the vein of the forgettable American Outlaws. For a while I thought Deadwood would fulfill my western needs, but it was canceled before it's time. While it was around, I learned a very important thing about Timothy Olyphant, who played Seth Bullock on the show. Timothy Olyphant was born to wear a cowboy hat. When he puts one on and throws on a drawl he becomes an insanely talented thing. Very Gary Cooper out of High Noon.

For this reason, I was very excited when I first heard about the show Justified, which was to feature Timothy Olyphant in a cowboy hat. As it turned out, Timothy Olyphant's cowboy hat would become so ubiquitous that some characters address his character as "you and your hat." Season 1 even features an episode in which Raylan Givens (Timothy Olyphant) loses his hat and is mildly distressed until he is reunited with it at the end of the episode.

At this point you may be thinking that Justified is just a show about a guy and his cowboy hat, but it is much more than that. Justified is based on a character from some Elmore Leonard stories and follows the adventures of a U.S. Marshal who, after some drama in Miami, is reassigned to his hometown in Eastern Kentucky. Here he has several run-ins with Boyd Crowder, played by the genius Walton Goggins, who was once his best friend, but is now a born-again Christian/all-purpose outlaw. Their clashes become the highlight of the show. Where Raylan is cool, but deadly, Boyd is hot-headed, and also deadly.

While not set in the West during the 1800s, Justified still plays like something of a hard-boiled western. The stories and dialogue are pure hard-boiled detective pulp and the setting of backwoods Kentucky is almost as foreign as the West once was. The result is one of the best written, tightest acted shows on the air.



Find the first season of Justified in our catalog here!

entry.title: Exit Through the Gift Shop
entry.content:
In preparation for the upcoming Oscars, I picked up Exit Through the Gift Shop, nominated for Documentary (Feature). The film features Thierry Guetta, a French immigrant now living in L.A. Thierry is obsessed with filming. Anything that can be filmed, he films. When he discovers that his cousin is a street artist going by the name Space Invader, Thierry begins filming Space Invader's installations. Soon, Thierry expands to other street artists, including Shepard Fairey, the man best known for the red and blue Obama poster. Under pressure from Fairey, Thierry claims that he is making a documentary about street art. However, he actually has no intention to make a film and is just filming for the sake of filming.

Thierry's ultimate goal is to meet the increasingly famous but extremely elusive British street artist Banksy. The two eventually meet and filming begins. When we see Banksy it is either from behind or from the front with his face blacked out and his voice distorted. Concerned with what he sees as the commercialization of street art, Banksy forces Thierry to actually make the film, and things spiral out of control. The "film" is a disaster and Banksy takes over. Suddenly, instead of Banksy and other artists being the subject of the documentary, the filmmaker becomes the subject. What ensues when Thierry starts his own art is jaw dropping. Some have called parts or all of this film a hoax but nothing has been proven. Whether or not it was real did not matter to me. I enjoyed learning about the world of street art and the lengths artists go to to keep their identities secret. The filmmaking style of handheld cameras, lower quality film, and wordless music, was well-suited to the subject. I will be interested to see if the film wins the Oscar.

For a look at the first few minutes of Exit Through the Gift Shop check out the video below.

entry.title: A river of waste.
entry.content: There have been a number of food and "food production" documentaries out within the last two years with the most popular one being Food Inc.. Last night I saw another good one called, A river of waste. This deals more with the pollutants produced in the poultry industry such as chicken litter, arsenic, antibiotics and growth hormones. For the most part, we believe that these substances are contained withing the facilities in which they are being produced but this documentary exposes that idea as false. See the trailer below to see if you're interested.

entry.title: Thirst (2009)
entry.content:
Thirst is the latest film from Chan-wook Park of Vengeance Trilogy fame (Sympathy for Mr. Vengeance, Oldboy, Lady Vengeance). It tells the story of a priest whose life is changed when he becomes a vampire. In the strictest sense, it is a vampire love story. However, it is a Chan-wook Park vampire love story, which means it's delightfully twisted, darkly humorous, fantastically violent, and bizarrely erotic. Yes, I do love my adverbs. If you can't overstate something, why even state it. That's what I always say.

Back to the movie. If you're looking to fill a Twilight void, Thirst is not your tea cup. Thirst is probably closer to the True Blood spectrum of vampire romance, but more bizarre, if you can imagine that. It turns many of the vampire romance tropes on their head. The most fun being had with the whole "will he or won't he turn the girl he loves" trope.

All vampire drama aside, Thirst is just a beautifully shot film. Chan-wook Park has a way with saturated colors that is quite remarkable, his use of greens, whites, and reds in particular. Whether you love vampire movies or just beautiful movies with a fun story, Thirst is a good pick.



Check out Thirst in the library catalog!

entry.title: Brick (2006)
entry.content:
Brick (2006) is a film that no matter how well you describe it, it still kind of sounds like a tacky idea and it easily could have been. A hard-boiled noir style detective film set in a modern-day high school? Hmm. But let me assure you that great care was taken with the specifics of the film that make this setup work surprisingly well. Joseph Gordon-Levitt (Inception, 500 Days of Summer) stars as Brendan, a quiet loner who acts as the gumshoe in this movie. He's lost contact with an ex-girlfriend at school who was straying into the world of drug trafficking and wants to make sure she's okay. When she turns up dead, he begins a quest for answers through the underground world of popular kids, the drama vamps and the super-smart geeks.

See? Still sounds a little tacky doesn't it? What saves the film from collapsing under the ridiculous setup is the script and the performances. The characters play the roles like they're actually in a 1940's detective film complete with rapid-fire speech and archaic slang that takes a little effort to follow. All the film noir tropes are here: the smart detective who knows how to take a punch, the bombshell who can't be trusted, the menacing kingpin and his muscle-bound henchman. This is a film that doesn't insult the viewer's intelligence and succeeds by playing the whole thing straight with nary a wink to suggest that the situations are taking place in an out-of-context environment. The plot becomes convoluted as double-crossing and lies start to twist the narrative.

This is certainly no "Disney's High School Detective" sort of film. The violence and drug content makes it clearly intended for an adult audience. It's a smart, classy and surprisingly emotional film that succeeds despite its inability to be described in a satisfying way. Definitely recommended.

entry.title: The Big Bang Theory
entry.content: After receiving recommendations from a number of friends for the TV show The Big Bang Theory, I decided it was finally time to check it out. I sat down to watch a couple of episodes of the first season and ended up watching six back to back. The show, a half hour comedy, features physicists, roommates, and super geniuses Sheldon and Leonard. Settled comfortably into nerddom, their lives are interrupted with the arrival of a new neighbor, a blond waitress named Penny. Leonard, the more social of the two, is immediately interested, but Sheldon is taken aback and does not welcome Penny's intrusion into his ordered existence. Also featuring engineer friends Howard (ultimate nerd and wannabe ladies' man) and Raj (unable to even talk to women), The Big Bang Theory is hilarious. For its over-the-top but still believable characters and laugh out loud situations (such as when all four guys end up dressing as The Flash for Halloween), I highly recommend this show.

entry.title: 3D or not to 3D
entry.content:
A while back I posted an article on this blog called In Praise of Black and White. In it I mentioned that the invention of color film brought about a number of films that focused on color shock effects and explosions rather than focusing on the story. I believe that many of the films made today would not seem as good to us if we were forced to watch them in black and white. Today we have a rise in another new gimmick format called 3D.
This is not the first time that 3D films have been attempted. 3D films have a history going back before the 1950s. I dont want to go into a history of 3D films, but I will say that the 3D technology used today works much better than the 3D of the 50s and 60s. It seems like almost everyone is jumping on the 3D bandwagon and films that were originally planned for 2D release have been re-mastered to give a 3D effect regardless of whether the 3D effect adds to the film or not. I have been told that Peter Jackson has thought about re-mastering the Lord of the Rings Trilogy in 3D and that George Lucas has mentioned doing the same thing for his Star Wars films. The question I must ask is whether 3D is really worth it? My answer might surprise you. Yes, I believe it is, however, I dont feel that every film needs 3D and in fact might be hampered by it. Some films work great in 3D and as we improve the technology and how directors use it I hope to see some great films produced in 3D.

One of my favorite films is the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz. At the time the film was made, black and white was king. Color filmmaking was expensive. The first two or three times I saw The Wizard of Oz I watched it on a black and white TV (yes, Im that old). There really wasnt a difference between Kansas and the Land of Oz; but the story grabbed me. I came to love the film before I ever saw it in color. When I finally saw the film in color the difference was amazing. Oz became an even more magical place. The use of color enhanced the story, but did not drive the story. The same can be said of todays 3D effects. In a good film, it should enhance the story without distracting from it. Nothing will change the need for a film to have a good story. A bad 3D movie is still just a bad movie. Or is it?

With todays technology 3D has two dangers that can take a good film and destroy it. The first is a dimming of the brightness and colors of the picture. Cinematographers are going to need to take this into account when filming. The picture needs to be brighter for the effect not to muddy up the picture. The second is distraction. In the 50s and 60s films tried to show off their 3D effects by having things seemingly come out of the screen towards you. Today many films try to do the same thing. Recently, I purchased a 3D TV, not because I wanted 3D, but because I got a good deal on it. To try it out I obtained a copy of the new Alice in Wonderland and watched it. I saw this film in 3D in the theaters, but have watched it twice in 2D since. I do like the 3D version better. I did, however, find some of the effects distracting. As I said, 3D is great for making things pop out of the screen, but I found myself watching a dragonfly as it sailed out of screen into my family room when the focus of the story and action was in the frame. There was a nice WOW factor to the dragonfly, but there really wasnt a point to having it fly out into my room. For me 3D works best when I feel like Im looking out a window. The window may be sitting still, moving, riding a roller coaster, or soaring over a sky line. I like having the sense of perspective that 3D gives me, just dont throw things in my face all time and dont think 3D will make your movie better. If a film doesnt work in 2D it wont work in 3D and it might just be hampered by it.

entry.title: Mugabe and the White African
entry.content:
Life is hard enough without the added pressures of the truly horrific and ugly things that people can do to one another. Without straying into the politics of race and class in Zimbabwe Africa, this documentary follows a white farmer from Zimbabwe as he continues his court battle to keep is land after Robert Mugabe, the president, changes the Zimbabwe constitution and starts a new land redistribution program. The Blacks from Zimbabwe don't want the Whites to be there and the Whites don't want to leave nor do they have anywhere else they can go since they are "legal" citizens of the country. The White farmers were eventually forced from their land when their property was burned down. The police and the military would not protect them. Some of the farmers are dead, some have disappeared and others have moved to Harare.
Warning: The extreme acts of violence contained in this documentary may be triggering to some.



If you still would like to see this documentary, it can be found by clicking here.

entry.title: Scott Pilgrim vs. the World
entry.content:
I wasnt sure what to expect when I first put Scott Pilgrim vs. the World in my DVD player. It was not even close to what I got. For those who are not familiar with the plot Scott Pilgrim [Michael Cera], the bass player in a small band, has fallen for the new cool girl in town, Ramona Flowers [Mary Elizabeth Winstead]. In order to date her he must first defeat her seven evil exes. Scott has baggage of his own. When he first sees Ramona he is dating Knives Chau [Ellen Wong] in a relationship that if it ever went beyond the hand-holding stage would have him arrested for statutory rape in several states. His relationship prior to Knives was with the lead singer of a number one band that is, of course, Knives' favorite group and prior to this (I told you he had baggage) he dated the drummer of his group, who is obviously still holding a grudge, but stays around for the music. His roommate is gay, who understands and is happy that Scott isnt, and in many cases offers the best advice, but also broadcasts Scotts failures quicker than you can say, How did you do that?

This is not the type of film I normally watch. However, it rises above others of its ilk by turning Scott's life into a videogame, complete with scores and cash when the villains are defeated, as well as extra lives and points. Each evil ex is stronger than the prior one, ending with "The Boss Level of the game- the 7th ex who holds the fate of not only Scott and Ramona in his hands, but that of his band as well. I became entranced, which surprised me, not only because the approach kept the movie from becoming a sad, sappy comedy, but because I was having a blast trying to figure out the video game references. Obvious ones, at least to me, included Dragon Ball Z, Serious Sam (computer version), and almost all of the Mario Bros. games. I think I also caught a couple of references to Gauntlet and Tron.

This is not going to be everyone's favorite film. My wife says she hated it even though I heard her laughing at bits all the way through. I think the movie was aimed at the under thirty crowd, but those of us sixty and under that were in on the early days of video games will find it entertaining as well.

entry.title: The sweethearts of the prison rodeo
entry.content: Last Friday I decided to scan the shelves in the library and pick up something random but interesting. I came across a DVD called, The Sweethearts of Prison Rodeo. The title alone is interesting. This documentary film is about inmates housed in the Oklahoma State Penitentiary. Once a year, every since 1940, the male inmates have been allowed to participate in a rodeo that serves as a short reprieve for them and entertainment for non-inmates. Anyone is welcome to attend. In 2007, a decision was made to give women the opportunity to participate in the rodeo. A group of women decided to put together a rodeo team and compete head-to-head with the men. This documentary shows both the men and womens competitions but it is mainly about the lives of women in the Oklahoma State Penitentiary and their rodeo team. Please be advised that some of the scenes in the rodeo portion contain severe injuries, blood, broken bones and others have compared this to a Gladiator-Like atmosphere.

entry.title: Shoot 'Em Up
entry.content:
Sometimes there is nothing better than a good shoot em up movie. I love to watch what I know are impossible stunts and a lone man or woman going up against impossible odds and coming out ahead. Die Hard was the first movie I remember seeing of this type, though Im sure there were earlier ones.
My new favorite in this genre has the honest title of Shoot em Up. This 2007 movie stars Clive Owen as a man named Smith who accidentally finds himself in the middle of everything after he comes to the aid of a pregnant women in labor who for some unknown reason is being attacked by a group of thugs. Smith is a loner who seems to have a thing for carrots which, like Bugs Bunny, he always seems to be eating or amazingly using as a deadly weapon. The villain in the move is an ex-government profiler (excuse me, I mean a forensic behavioral consultant) name Hertz played perfectly by Paul Giamatti. You might remember him as John Adams in the HBO mini-series of the same name. He effectively steals every scene he is in, which in this movie is difficult.
I wont be giving away much if I tell you that in the first few minutes of the movie the girl dies, the baby doesnt and it is the baby who was the real target of the thugs. If you like gunfire, over- the-top stunts and tongue-in-cheek, dark, dry humor youll like Shoot em Up. It has everything you want in a good shoot em up: gunfire, blood, the whore with a heart of gold, heavy metal music, stunts, corrupt politicians, but I dont remember right now if it had a kitchen sink.

entry.title: Hoarders
entry.content: Hoarders is an A&E reality television show that focuses on people that engage in compulsive hoarding. I watched the first four episodes and could not believe my eyes. There are people that collect things, store things and buy knick-knacks, and then there are hoarders. Hoarders are the extreme versions of those that like to collect and store things in their homes. Some people hoard junk, others hoard clothes, food, and animals. Hoarders seem to come in all types. This is a reality television show and can be quite shocking at times so viewer discretion is advised. To see a sample of what this show is like, watch the advertisement for it on A&E below.

entry.content:
There are a lot of television shows involving criminal investigations and murder. The public must love them otherwise there wouldnt be so many. I have to admit that Ive been sucked into a few of them. Ive seen:

Foyles War
JAG
The Wire
The Shield (We no longer have this one)
The Closer
Bones
Mentalist
Numb3rs
Dead Zone
The Jesse Stone Series
Over the weekend I picked up season one of Criminal Minds on dvd. This show follows an elite team of FBI criminal profilers that specialize in creating detailed profiles of criminals after a crime as taken place in a local community. Despite what you might think of profiling, this show does an excellent job of showing how profiling helps catch criminals quickly. entry.title: A Prophet (2009)
entry.content:
English-language adaptations of foreign films are rarely any good and one of my least favorite phenomenons. The magic of the original usually gets lost. On the other hand, foreign-language remakes of US films? Kind of fantastic, if you ignore the recent Zhang Yimou remake of Blood Simple. Granted I only know of one other than that, but it is excellent enough to prove the rule. Jacques Audiard's The Beat That My Heart Skipped updates the forgotten Harvey Keitel film Fingers with genius results.

Audiard's follow-up to that bit of awesome is the fantastically tense A Prophet, which features the best performance since Jeremy Renner last appeared on screen. Tahir Rahim plays Malik, a young Arab man imprisoned in a French jail who matures into a full-fledged criminal after adopted by the Corsican mafia. It becomes something of a prison David and Goliath story, almost.


Malik survives prison. He grows up in prison. He learns to read, he learns to kill. Whether he's a success story is up to the viewer. What's not in question is the fact that Audiard has painted another masterful portrait of crime.

Check out A Prophet in our catalog.

entry.title: Just Wright
entry.content: Just Wright is the latest movie out starring Queen Latifah. She debuts as Leslie Wright, a physical trainer/therapist that works to rehabilitate personal injuries. She and her sister get invited to a famous NBA basketball player's mansion for a party where Wright's sister seduces the only the single guy there. Wright's sister becomes engaged to McKnight when he suddenly falls and injures himself in one of his games and shatters his knee. Now McKnight needs to hire a personal trainer to get him back in shape, but where will he find one? You guessed it... in comes Leslie Wright to spend and awful lot of time stretching and exercising in close quarters to get him rehabilitated except they both come to realize that they might have feeling for each other. Who will be Scott McKnight's choice be? Get ready for a few good laughs and a few sad moments. This film is rated PG and is both a drama and a romantic comedy.

entry.title: Citizen Kane
entry.content:
The camera opens on a "no trespassing" sign, slowly panning up and over the gate of a formally lavish estate, crossing property that reminds me of a dark twisted version of Michael Jacksons Neverland estate. The mansion on the hill looks like it came out of an old horror movie. With each cut the scene reveals more of the estate, finally ending on a close-up of a house covered with snow. A slow zoom out reveals the house to be in a small snowglobe resting in someones hand. Cut to a set of mustached lips, filling the screen and uttering one of the most famous words in film history."Rosebud. The snowglobe falls from the hand holding it to break on the floor below. Thus ends the life of Charles Foster Kane, rich newspaper tycoon and the story of one journalists search for the meaning of his last words revealing the life of his subject in a series of flashback that tends to result in more questions than answers.

Citizen Kane, loosely based on the life of publisher William Randolph Hurst, is perhaps one of the greatest movies that almost never saw the light of day. It is said that Hurst did everything he could to stop this film and when it was finished refused to allow advertising for it in any of his papers. Orson Wells has always claimed that Kane was not based on any one person, however the story so closely follows the life of Hurst that this statement is hard to believe.

Citizen Kane was a box office flop when it was first released, perhaps because Hurst controlled most of the major newspapers at the time. It has since become known as one of the greatest films ever made. Kane is the man who had everything he ever wanted and perhaps nothing that he wanted was what he really needed. Kane was a man of principle, the voice of the people, and then became something else. What exactly I will leave to your judgment. He was willing to look at both sides of an issue and then choose a side to fight upon.sometimes fighting against himself, as you can see from these two Charles Foster Kane quotes. The first when he is informed that his newspaper is currently losing a million dollars a year

You're right, I did lose a million dollars last year. I expect to lose a million dollars this year. I expect to lose a million dollars *next* year. You know, Mr. Thatcher, at the rate of a million dollars a year, Ill have to close this place in... 60 years.

And when he is lambasted for attacking the greed of the public transit system

As Charles Foster Kane who owns eighty-two thousand, six hundred and thirty-four shares of public transit - you see, I do have a general idea of my holdings - I sympathize with you. Charles Foster Kane is a scoundrel. His paper should be run out of town. A committee should be formed to boycott him. You may, if you can form such a committee, put me down for a contribution of one thousand dollars.

Citizen Kane is one of those movies that everyone should watch at least once. It reminds us that even those in power are human. Or as Kane says of his life, You know, Mr. Bernstein, if I hadn't been very rich, I might have been a really great man

Do you ever find the meaning of Kanes last words? If you watch closely you will, but it might give you more to think about than if you had not. And maybe, when it comes down to it, that is what makes a great movie great.

entry.title: Sex and the City 2
entry.content:
The TV show "Sex and the City" was superb because it was funny and sprinkled in a hint of truth which caused most people to compare it to their real life expectations of dating. It really was a first-of-its-kind after the Ally McBeal show. The first Sex and the City movie was okay. It had a few good laughs and somewhat of a clich happy ending. entry.title: Bright Leaves (2003)
entry.content:
When you turn on Bright Leaves, the first thing you hear is the languid and warm voice of Ross McElwee, your narrator for the whole of this film. This is a staple of McElwee's brand of personal documentary. He is best known for Sherman's March, a movie in which he sets out to make a documentary about the lingering effects of Sherman's March on the South, but ends up making one about his ex-girlfriends. McElwee doesn't so much document a thing as document his train of thought, however convoluted, about a thing.

Bright Leaves sees the tobacco industry getting the McElwee treatment. McElwee has discovered a movie from the 1950s that he believes is based on the life of his grandfather. The movie, Bright Leaf, tells the story of the rise and fall of a tobacco magnate seeking to mass produce cigarettes. Just as with Sherman's March, what starts as an investigation of a film turns into an exploration of the addictive qualities of filming and the impact of tobacco farming on the economy of North Carolina.


McElwee does not partake of Michael Moore's version of narration. There is no editorializing. While Michael Moore stretches the bounds of non-fiction film with his editing choices, McElwee fully acknowledges the potential artifice and invites doubt of his images because he shares it.

While I could go on and on about the geekier elements of Bright Leaves, as much as anything it is a subtly amusing documentary. McElwee is always an excellent tour guide and his frustrations with his subject matter always translate to the viewer. I cannot imagine anyone regretting checking out any of his films. Bright Leaves can be found in our catalog here.

entry.title: The Art of the Steal
entry.content: The Art of the Steal is an unusual but very interesting documentary. When I think of art theft I usually think of Sean Connery and Catherine Zeta Jones in the movie Entrapment where someone breaks in a museum in the middle of the night and steals a couple of paintings. This documentary is about the collusion of several non-profits and charities and along with a city government to aquire a private art collection against the expressed wishes of Albert Barnes after his death. The film carefully traces out the rise and fall of the Barnes Foundation and its estimated contents worth over 10 billion dollars. The Barnes collection contains some orginial works by Van Gogh, Renoir, Cezanne and Matisse and everyone wants to get their hands on them. What's shocking are the various and nefarious ways in which non-profit corporations can behave like private corporations.

entry.title: A Groundhog Day of Christmas Carols or How I was hooked into watching the same story over and over again.
entry.content:
For most of us its Christmas time and here at the library the Christmas movies just fly off the shelves. Like most people I have my favorites: A Christmas Story, Desk Set, It's a Wonderful Life. My all time favorite however is A Christmas Carol based on the story by Charles Dickens. Not just one version mind you, but all of them. At Christmastime I find myself watching movie after movie version of A Christmas Carol like Bill Murray in Groundhog Day, repeating the same story over and over and over again. I can do without Tiny Tim. I can do without Bob Cratchit, or Scrooge's nephew who always invites his Uncle, although he appears to hate him, over for Christmas dinner. Oh, but Scrooge on the other hand. Here is a character who is almost most universally hated. But I dont hate him. In my cubical at work I keep a picture of him posted year round just to remind me, not of who he was, but who he became. Scrooge to me is a wonderful reminder that no matter how bad a person may be, he can become something different. When I think of Scrooge I dont think of a skinflint. I think of a man who changed and it gives me hope, for some reason, in the future.
The story has been done many times over the years. I would like to share with you some of my favorite versions of A Christmas Carol. I hope you like them as much as I do. If Ive left out your favorite, Im sorry. For the sake of brevity, Ive even left out a couple of my own.

A Christmas Carol (1951) Sometimes known simply as the Alistair Sims Christmas Carol. Alistair Sim defined Scrooge and a wonderful job he did of it too. It may not be the best Christmas Carol, but its become the standard against which all others are judged.

A Christmas Carol (1984) George C. Scott as Scrooge, I just couldnt see it. Scott makes a gruff Scrooge, but just how was he going to become the giddy Scrooge at the end I couldn't get. I had forgotten just how great an actor George C. Scott was. This has become my second favorite Christmas Carol and my favorite transition on Christmas morning.

Mr. Magoos Christmas Carol This was the first version of A Christmas Carol that I ever saw. It holds a special place in my heart. Magoo somehow, someway is a perfect Scrooge, squinty-eyed and angry, and he makes the transition to jolly almost as well as George C. Scott.

Scrooge A Christmas Carol with singing and dancing. This is my favorite version of A Christmas Carol. I find myself singing Thank You Very Much over and over again after watching it, much to the dismay of my co-workers. I find it interesting that when it was first released on VHS tape Scrooges descent into hell was cut from film. It was four years after my first viewing that I finally saw a print with this scene intact. It is one of the best scenes in the movie, so I'm glad that the DVDs have kept it.

These last two are not strictly A Christmas Carol, But they follow the same pattern.

Scrooged Bill Murry as a TV executive full of ratings greed. Take A Christmas Carol and modernize it, stand it on its head and throw pies at it and you have Scrooged. This is one that you just shouldnt miss. Its not as touching as most versions, but it is has some of the best laughs of any film.

An American Christmas Carol Starring Henry Winkler as Sam Slade. Set just after the depression, Henry Winkler makes a surprisingly good Scrooge-type character. Sadly, the library doesnt own this title right now. But if you can find it while flipping channels this holiday season its worth checking out. His Scrooge is definitely not the Fonze.

entry.title: Project Runway: Season 1 & Eleven Minutes
entry.content:
There are few things that alleviate end-of-semester stress for me like movies with good explosions (the movie doesn't have to be good, just the explosiosn), bad sci-fi (think whatever the latest sequel of Species is), or trashy reality television (Queen of Trash, Real World/Road Rules Challenge). These will alleviate pretty much any kind of stress like magic.

After the travesty that was the Project Runway: Season 8 finale I was in the mood for days when winners of this show didn't send saggy granny panties down the runway. It was at this time that I noticed Eleven Minutes, the documentary chronicling Jay McCarroll's road to show at Fall Fashion Week in 2006, on the shelves.

Jay is arguably the most fascinating of all the Project Runway winners. Some might say he squandered his opportunity with the way he turned down the money and Banana Republic apprenticeship he won, but he's really just a designer who doesn't like to compromise his vision in any way. Plus, can anyone really see this boy

or this dress

fitting in at Banana Republic? Jay just likes to design his way, and sometimes that means he falls completely off the radar. That starts to make more sense when you listen to him talk about the way he handles pressure, real or imagined. It seems to me that he can't deal with all his promise. His own hype seems to intimidate him.

After watching Eleven Minutes I was in the mood for some season 1 Project Runway in a big way. Three of my all time favorites reside in that season, Jay, Kara Saun, and Austin Scarlett, so it was nice to go back and remember their shenanigans. Plus, I still lust after this scarf

Once upon a time, I attempted to make my own version, but it did not turn out at all well.

Project Runway is not the trashiest of reality, but it's decently trashy. Enough so that it provides a welcome distraction from end-of-the-year stress. You can find Project Runway Season 1-6 in our catalog here and Eleven Minutes here.

entry.title: Discovering Ireland
entry.content: Over the the holiday weekend I watched Discovering Ireland with my mom. In addition to feature films and documentaries, the Monroe County Public Library also has travel videos. Ive been thinking about going to Ireland for a long time so I decided check this dvd out. It's very thorough and gives the highlights of each region and county of Ireland. It seems as though each county is famous for something. The scenery is breath-taking and my mom commented afterwards that she felt like she had actually been on vacation. If youre thinking about going to Ireland or just curious about its people and culture then this would be a good travel video to watch. Youll learn about famous castles, cemeteries, lakes, how harps are made, Guinness, hurling, road bowling and more.

entry.title: The Messenger
entry.content: When injured Staff Sergeant Will Montgomery (Ben Foster) returns home from his tour of duty in Iraq he is greeted with some unwelcome news. He is assigned to the Casualty Notifcation Team under Captain Tony Stone (Woody Harrelson). Their duty is to notify the next of kin when soldiers have been killed in battle. Captain Stone trains Montgomery in the precise protocol necessary to perform his duties. Though he tries, he cannot prepare Montgomery for the range of responses he will get from the family members he must notify. As the pair work together in their difficult assignment a genuine friendship begins to develop as Montgomery attempts to adjust to life back home and Stone struggles with recent sobriety. Along the way an unexpected reaction by a dead soldier's wife (Samantha Morton) captures Montgomery's attention. The Messenger is packed with excellent performances, from the small- Steve Buscemi as a grieving father who receives bad news less than gracefully- to the main characters. Foster's nuanced portrayal of a man maintaining a strong appearance on the outside while crumbling inside is spot on. And Harrelson, nominated for an Oscar, gives a powerful performance as the tough captain who hides his fragile side behind his sunglasses and adherence to procedure. A different take on a war film, The Messenger is a timely, affecting movie.

entry.title: Hachi: A Dog's Tale
entry.content: If you're an animal or pet owner, you'll love this one. You'll also want to keep a box of Kleenex close by. This is a G-rated, safe, and all ages appropriate film. The star character is Hachiko, an Akit Inu () or Japanese breed of a dog. This breed is well known for its intelligence and loyalty. In the movie, Hachi is abandoned at a train station and stays there until he is picked up. Parker Wilson (Richard Gere) finds the abandoned dog as a puppy in the train station and immediately forms a bond with him. At some point in the film Parker (Gere's character) gets sick and what happens next is truly amazing. I say truly amazing because this movie is based on a true story. The library has seven copies of this movie. Although it's listed as being in the Children's Department, I think adults will enjoy this as well. Take a look at the trailer below.

entry.title: Unthinkable
entry.content: What a great thriller! Im a fan of Samuel L. Jackson. I like him because hes always the good guy whos just trying to make it. He conveys this so well in every movie. The theme is always the same: Im Just a regular guy, trying to make it in this big bad world, doing my own thing, minding my own business when. (Insert some outside tragedy) occurs and interrupts my life completely. This is usually the theme of Samuel L. Jacksons roles. In Unthinkable, its the opposite! Samuel L. Jackson is the bad guy. It reminds me of Denzel Washington who also had so many good guy movies until he was in Training Day and then he received an Oscar for that.

entry.title: Under Our Skin
entry.content: WOW! WOW! WOW! I strongly recommend that everyone see this documentary! There are ticks in Indiana and this makes this documentary relevant to our community. I heard about it from a patron at our library and decided to place a reserve on the next available copy. You can do that also by CLICKING HERE! I took it home not expecting very much and ended up watching it twice. I also watched the special features at the end of the disc. How in the world could there be such a controversy over Lyme Disease? Without getting into the politics of this, the debate is very simple. Some doctors believe that Lyme Disease is a very rare occurrence, and when it does occur, it is thought of as treatable with antibiotics within two weeks time or less. On the other side are doctors that claim that Lyme Disease is a life-long chronic disease that can take years to treat or you might just have it for life. I had always believed that Lyme Disease was easily treatable, but now, that may not be the case. This is the kind of documentary to watch with an open mind. When scientists are pitted against each other, (like some in the Global Warming debate) it's kind of easy to just side with the established opinion of what has been written in journals and texts. But, sometimes the treatments offered in those journals and texts may not be the best treatment for everyone. And then there are the health insurance companies. The insurance companies prefer not to hear that Lyme Disease cases take years to treat. If you've never heard of Lyme Disease (or even is you have) you really should see this documentary.

entry.title: Connections
entry.content:
While in college I took a class that was known more by its unofficial name What is History? than by the real name and number of the course. In truth, the real name escapes me even now. But Ive never forgotten the course. It was one of the more interesting classes that I took. I even remember, by heart, every question on the final exam, or should I say the only question on the final exam. Based on your assigned readings and our discussions in class, what is history? End of exam. If I had watched the series Connections with James Burke I might have had a different answer to that question than the one I gave. Not that Im not proud of my answer. It was, after all, the only time I ever scored an A+ on any essay question.
Connections presents history and invention as a series of interrelated events. Different needs resulting in invention and invention leading to events and still further invention. Almost like a series of Rube Goldberg contraptions. It asks the question, What does the invention of the saddle stirrup have to do with the invention of the atomic bomb? James Burke will tell you that it is much more than you might think; because it was the invention of the stirrup that led from one invention to the next and one historic event to the next leading to the perceived need for something like the atomic bomb and the technology and funding to build it.
Produced by the BBC long enough ago that computers were barely out of the punch card stage, the material in this series amazingly doesnt feel dated. Even James Burkes suit is beginning to come back into style, though Im not sure I can say the same about his sideburns. Connections is entertaining and educational and it makes you see that history is more a connection of interrelated events than we might think and James Burke is an effective and easy to understand speaker. I watched the first episode, The Trigger Effect with my son recently, which focuses on the famous power blackout of 1965. His comment was Thats really scary. I try to watch this series about once every four or five years, just to keep things perspective.

entry.title: Skins (2007)
entry.content:
When Skins first started airing, I almost overlooked it. I'm generally pretty good at keeping up with British shows, but this one only had one actor I really recognized, Nicholas Hoult of About a Boy, and a concept that could've quickly worn thin. Degrassi was already fulfilling my teen show issue-of-the-week quotient and I wasn't sure Skins could achieve Degrassi's excellent balance of cheese and awesome. Lucky for me I gave it a try anyway.

As much as it hurts me to say, Skins actually addresses the same issues that Degrassi does, but in a more seamless fashion. Degrassi can sometimes feel a little after-school-special and try to take on too many issues. Often you see teen characters becoming caricatures on popular teen shows, but Skins let's its characters breathe in their roles. They become people.

Another fun thing about Skins is that it gets awesome guests, Bill Bailey (Black Books) and Peter Capaldi (The Thick of It) being highlights. Also, most people now know who Dev Patel is, but this is the show that gave him his start. With its candor about sexuality, drug use, and so on, this show transcends The CW's brand of "scandalous" teen programming, but you'll also find that it's a surprisingly sweet show. Prepare for Sid and Cas to tear you apart. Don't say I didn't warn you.



Find Skins Series 1 & 2 in our catalog here.

entry.title: Cabbage by Gaelic Storm
entry.content:
Gaelic Storm, a contemporary Celtic band, has a new CD out, entitled Cabbage. I am a big fan of Gaelic Storms' music; they excellently combine traditional Celtic sounds and traditions with contemporary, often quirky lyrics and rhythms. They offer twists on traditional songs such as Johnny Tarr, Nancy Whiskey, and Tell Me Ma, but they also have their own story songs like "The Night I Punched Russell Crowe" or not letting "the truth get in the way of a good story." Though their story songs and twists on traditional Celtic tunes are enjoyable and fun, I personally love their instrumental music. They have a few lyrical, slower songs, but most of Gaelic Storm's music is lively and upbeat, and I especially like the mix of fiddle, bagpipes, and contemporary interpretation of the music.


If you are interested in Celtic music, especially lively Celtic rhythms and traditions, then I recommend checking out Gaelic Storm. We have several of their albums in our collection.

entry.title: Wolf Man vs Wolfman
entry.content:
When you think of famous movie monsters there are a select few that come to mind as classics: Frankenstein, Dracula, the Mummy, and the Wolf Man will be found on almost every list. Just recently I watched the The Wolfman, a remake of the 1941 Lon Chaney Jr. Classic film The Wolf Man. There are several differences in plot points between the two films, but I was surprised to notice that Universal had kept the look of The Wolfman basically the same in the remake as that of the 1941 classic.
Both films feature Lawrence Talbot, an innocent who only wants to do good, who after surviving a bite from a werewolf becomes a werewolf himself. In both films the father becomes something of a villain, albeit for different reasons. The remake is set about 50 years earlier, giving it a more gothic feel than the 1941 version. The Wolfman didnt do well in the theatres. Perhaps because it never really decided whether its focus was on Talbot the man or Talbot the werewolf, but I found both aspects equally interesting. The greatest horror to me was not in the blood and gore aplenty in the werewolf attacks, but in the treatment of Lawrence Talbot in the asylum when he is thought to be mad. It is a realistic portrayal of asylums of the time and that people were ever treated like this is something truly horrible.
Perhaps the greatest difference between the classic and the new is in what is shown. If you like blood and gore you will like the newer film. But I sometimes wonder if all of it was necessary. I think I would have found my imagination painting an even more gruesome picture of the attacks if it had been given the chance to do so. I think my wife saw a different movie. She watched the attacks with a pillow firmly held in front of her eyes. What she imagined, Im sure, was worse than what I saw. Today the classic Wolf Man movie is almost comedic in its effects and dialogue, but I remember as a child watching that old film scrunched inside of cabinet, with the door cracked just enough to watch the TV, hoping that The Wolf Man would not spot me.
My Final Word: The Wolfman tries to recreate the romance and drama of the old horror films while bringing the effects and gore level up to the present. It features a fine set of actors, Benicio Del Toro, Emily Blunt, and Anthony Hopkins who definitely fit their parts well. This film is as much a period piece as a horror film, and I enjoyed it. However, if you have the time, and can get over the 1941 effects, check out the original The Wolf Man as well.

entry.content: Sherman's March is a very different kind of documentary than what you might expect it to be. I bet if you had to guess, you would probably say that this is a documentary about William Tecumseh Sherman's burning of cities and towns in Georgia and in South Carolina. This is almost the true. During the making of the documentary, the film maker's girlfriend breaks up with him. The break-up disturbed him so much that he spends a good portion of the documentary on reconnecting with past girlfriends and exploring his love life. It's weird, it's funny, it's awkward and it's still serious. Check out the trailer below.

entry.title: Whale Warrior
entry.content: Recently I watched Whale Warrior. This is a documentary about one mans mission to stop illegal whale hunting. Illegal whale hunting is supposed to be overseen by the International Whaling Commission but sometimes a few hunters manage to get by without being caught and other hunters finds ways to circumvent the law. For those that do, Paul Watson is the lone ranger there to greet them and chase them away. Paul Watson has been protecting whales for thirty three years. This documentary is about him and his encounters with those that choose to hunt whales illegally.

entry.title: Nip/Tuck
entry.content: I'm still waiting on some of my holds to come in, so in the meantime I picked up season one of Nip/Tuck from a sorting cart. This is a television show that is based on two doctors that are in business together as plastic surgeons. As they receive more and more clients, they realize that while they may be excellent doctors and surgeons, they are not psychologists. Before every plastic surgery occurs, there is an interview process to screen the patient for mental illness. The two doctors find that they need to hire an on-staff psychologist to sit with them in the interviews to screen out the candidates for which plastic surgery is not the best option. Each episode features a new patient and always starts with the statement, "So, tell us what it is that you don't like about yourself." Nip/Tuck has a total of six seasons. It is also not without controversy. It has been criticized by the Parents Television Council. This is definitely intended for adults and not for the squeamish and faint of heart. Beware that there are graphic surgical scenes, strong language, nudity and sex. If you can handle those, then prepare for an intense psychological thriller!

entry.title: The Perfect Getaway
entry.content:
First of let me say I am NOT a fan of Steve Zahn. He was perfect for the role of Lenny in That Thing You Do. But Ive found him at best annoying in every other role I've seen him in, which I will admit has not been a great many films. In The Perfect Getaway , however, he works perfectly as one half of a newly married couple hiking to a remote Hawaiian beach on their honeymoon. Everything is perfect until they link up with another couple who seem a little weapon happy. Add to this the information that another newlywed couple on a nearby island was recently found murdered and the suspects are yet another couple who have possibly escaped to this same area. Couples everywhere. Steve Zahn plays an annoying nerd very well. In this movie the annoying is turned way down, but he is still an uninformed nerd, however, when the time comes to take control of the situation he handles himself very well. The cast is rounded out with Milla Jovovich as his wife and Timothy Olyphant and Kiele Sanchez as one of the other other couples. entry.title: Degrassi: The Next Generation
entry.content:
There are many things about Canada that make it awesome, but the one I'm most fond of this week is its teen programming. Namely Degrassi: The Next Generation. As its tagline claims, "It goes there." And where does it go? Pretty much everywhere American teen programming is afraid to go. Homosexuality, school shootings, cutting, eating disorders, rape, teen pregnancy, and pretty much anything else a teen might have to deal with is given at least one episode on Degrassi. More importantly than just representing these various things, is the fact that they are acted out by regular cast members and not by characters who just show up for one episode to be the gay one or the one who considers abortion and are then shipped off to incidental character limbo. "It goes there," but not at all in an exploitative way. "It goes there" in an extremely responsible and mature fashion. In other words, it's just awesome.

Lucky for US teens, Degrassi now airs on Teen Nick. Those really lucky ones are probably already greedily consuming each new episode of Season 10, also known as "The Boiling Point." The rest of us are catching it online. If you want to see where it all began, you can find the early seasons of Degrassi: The Next Generation in our catalog.

entry.content: This is a fairly new tv show about ghosts. It's kind of like Touched by an Angel meets the dark side, but always with a happy ending. As the title suggests, there is one person in the show, the main character, that can see ghosts. Her special ability allows her to help the living communicate with the dead. The ghosts usually have some unresolved conflict that keeps them earth-bound. Once the conflict has been resolved, the ghosts can then travel toward the light. This tv show is light-hearted, funny, philosophical and at times scary. The library has the first three seasons of this show. Here is a very short clip.

entry.title: Crash (1996)
entry.content:
Once upon a time, a friend asked me what my favorite Cronenberg film was. I responded, "Crash." Because it is. Apparently this was the first time my friend had ever had someone claim that particular Cronenberg gem as their favorite. I'm not sure I'd say it's his best, but it's still one of my favorites. You see, dear readers, I have a thing for bodies as machines, or, as Vaughan (the always awesome Elias Koteas) puts it in the movie, "The reshaping of the human body by modern technology." Does that not sound delicious? I love robots an awful, awful lot, but human machines are even more awesome. With a human machine you get to skip right over the metaphor of the robot and jump right into the meat of just what it means to be a cyborg.

So what what is Crash about, beyond the reshaping of the human body? Well, James (James Spader), a film producer, falls in with a group of people who fetishize car crashes after being involved in a car crash that crushed his leg and killed the passenger of the other car involved. The film follows James as he sinks further and further into the world of car crash fetishists. I know, you're wondering where you can line up for this one, aren't you? To further tempt you, the trailer:


Line up here, folks! If you like human machines or are just curious about the twisted mind of David Cronenberg, you need to check out Crash.

entry.title: Zombieland
entry.content:
I had heard the buzz about Zombieland- how much fun it was and how great, but I didn't believe it. In my opinion it's hard to pull off a "funny" scary movie with much success. But Zombieland succeeds with quick dialogue, great action and a stellar cast. The main character, Columbus, is played by Jesse Eisenberg, a likeable geek, who give us insight into the ways one can survive in the United States of Zombies. He eventually joins forces with tough Tallahassee (a hilarious Woody Harrelson) who only wants to kill zombies and find a Twinkie. Along the way they meet up with Witchita and Little Rock a young woman and her little sister (Emma Stone and Abigail Breslin) who have discovered unique ways to survive their new reality. The foursome end up on a road trip to visit an LA amusement park, battling zombies all the while. Throw in a terrific cameo by Bill Murray when the group stops by his mansion and you have an incredibly entertaining, outright funny action/horror flick.
If you have already enjoyed Zombieland then you might want to give Shaun of the Dead a try. This is another rare funny/scary movie that succeeds and again features zombies. Poor slacker Shaun is thrust into the unlikely role of hero when zombies overrun London. This funny film is an amusing send up of traditional zombie fare.

entry.title: The Cove
entry.content: Last weekend I watched "The Cove". If you're like me and you watch all the previews before watching your new movie then you've heard of The Cove. This Oscar winning documentary film goes very deep inside Japans dolphin and whaling industry. It documents the systematic slaughter of dolphins for their meat. The slaughter of the dolphins is hidden away from public view in a place called the cove in Taijii, Japan. A team of people try to find this hidden cove and expose it to the rest of Japanese society and to the world at large. WARNING: This is a deeply disturbing film with very graphic scenes involving animal cruelty towards dolphins. Even given this, I found the documentary worthwhile and informative. I had no idea that such things occurred on a scale and magnitude as they did in this film.

entry.title: Jesse Stone: No Remorse
entry.content: No Remorse is the sixth movie in the Jesse Stone series based on the popular novels by Robert Parker. I've haven't read the books, but if the movies are good, then the books must be even better. In this movie, Jesse Stone is on a temporary suspension when three murders occur in the small town of Paradise, Massachusetts. Eventually the murders are solved and, as always, we never know what's going to happen with Jesse Stone. Is he going to be fired? Will he resign?

entry.title: The 10th Kingdom
entry.content:
Happy ever after didn't last as long as we'd hoped. Prince Wendell

Things are not what they should be in the Nine Kingdoms. Prince Wendell has been turned into a dog, his evil stepmother is loose and seeking his throne and the Troll Kingdom is attacking. Prince Wendells only hope of restoration lies with a janitor and his lovely daughter accidentally brought to the Nine Kingdoms through a magic mirror from a place the trolls call The 10th Kingdom, but we call New York City.

The 10th Kingdom is a miniseries that has become a family favorite in our house. Like
The Wizard of Oz, Its a Wonderful Life and O Brother Where Art Thou we try to watch this program at least once a year. Its not simply a fairy tale for children. There are subjects that some children would find disturbing. In fact, some adults might find them disturbing and they may not seem like fitting subjects for a family story. But then, the original fairy tales were not exactly for children either.

There are a lot of laughs in the 10th Kingdom. The father/janitor Tony, is played by John Larroquette, his daughter Virginia, by Kimberly Williams-Paisley. They are joined on their journey of redemption by Wolf (Scott Cohen), a character that steals almost every scene he is in. Wolf has developed a large crush on Virginia which poses problems as he is/was/might be in league with the evil Queen. The best lines are given to Wolf and Tony both of whom have the ability to provide a smirk out of even a simple line. One of my favorite exchanges occurs after Tony realizes just how Wolf feels about his daughter.

Tony: [about his relationship with Virginia] I need to know if your intentions are honorable.
Wolf: [very long pause as Wolf considers] No, not really.

And Virginias and Wolf relationship can best be summed up.

Wolf: I get the feeling you still don't completely trust me.
Virginia: I don't trust you at all! You tried to eat my grandmother.

There is nothing really unpredictable about the 10th Kingdom. You know things will work out in the end and there is only one big surprise, but it takes the standard fairy tale formula and turns it on its edge, adding just enough to keep you going. Where else are you going to find magic mushrooms singing A Whiter Shade of Pale"- something that happened to me often in the sixties. Perhaps I shouldn't have mentioned that. The ending, even though I have now seen it eight times, still gets to me, but not for the reason you might think. It deals with a very uncomfortable issue. One we dont like to talk about, but we are aware of. It is very much in contrast with the humor of the rest of the story, and perhaps that makes it more palatable and it might help those who have undergone something like it their lives.

Troll: This could be a long torture session.
Virginia: I'll tell you anything you wanna know.
Troll: Torture first, then you talk. It's better that way. Rush a torture, ruin a torture.

My Final Word: Try not to think about the queens dancing shoes. I dont.

entry.title: American Violet
entry.content: This past weekend I watched American Violet. It was based on a true story and every time I read that on the back cover of a dvd, I immediately want to watch it. Apparently Texas had a state law whereby the word of one criminal informant is enough evidence to have you arrested. This actually happened to a woman in Texas. She was innocent and with help from the ACLU, she sued the district attorney and won. This movie is about that case.

entry.title: Monarch of the Glen
entry.content:
I have been watching more TV series as opposed to movies, and I appreciate the capacity for more character and plot development over a longer period of time, instead of having to sum everything up in 2 hours. I have recently become caught up in the BBC television series Monarch of the Glen, which is set in Scotland and focuses on Archie MacDonald, who finds out that he is now the laird or landowner of his family's estate. The show is full of quirky characters who are at times both lovable and frustrating, especially Archie's father, Hector, who is my favorite character in the series.

The show has aspects of drama, but it is also comical, due to the different characters and their personalities. And, the beautiful setting of the Scottish highlands is a perfect backdrop for the situations and problems inherent with running and trying to maintain a centuries old estate in the 21st century. The old traditions conflict with the new necessities, and the characters act and adapt to new situations as they try to save the estate.

Monarch of the Glen offers beautiful scenery, endearing characters, and a good premise. If you enjoy series that are driven by characters and setting, as well as Scottish culture, I would highly recommend checking out Monarch of the Glen. The library owns seasons 1-4.

entry.title: OK Go, "Of the Blue Colour of the Sky"
entry.content:
OK Go have always been impressive with their videos, but with their latest album, "Of the Blue Colour of the Sky," and separation from Capitol Records theyve segued into certifiably awesome. First there was the fight over the ability to embed their videos. This never made any sense to me, especially when marketing a band that built so much of its name off the spread of viral videos. Luckily, State Farm was there to back the boys on their distribution of the video for This Too Shall Pass. Never have I minded product placement less.



Beyond that, theres always been the fact that OK Go regularly stages contests and such encouraging people to remix their videos. Thats not so much a new thing, with bands like Radiohead and Arcade Fire, releasing their songs deconstructed to make it easier for those who might want to remix them, but its still an awesome thing.

This most recent bout of awesome is the one that has me most excited. Today I finally watched the video for End Love. It was all kinds of stop-motion, photobombed by a duck goodness.

No, to participate in this contest all you need to do is download their video (for free!), upload it to your Facebook page (with no mention that they require credit!), and share the link with them. They have given folks free reign to upload this video anywhere. Anywhere. Without even asking that we link back to them. Do you even know how awesome that is? entry.content: If you followed politics closely back in 2003, you might remember the CIA leak controversy involving the name Valerie Plame. Just how far is the reporter willing to go to keep her source confidential? Youll have to watch it to found. Our library has two copies of Nothing But the Truth.

entry.title: Post Apocalyptic Films
entry.content:
I recently did a book list on post apocalyptic fiction- one of my favorite sub-genres, which got me thinking about the same types of films. There's nothing I like better than a well made life after the end of the world movie. They contain everything that I enjoy in a movie- bleak landscapes, action, danger, creatures- especially during the summer. So with that in mind I've created a short list of my favorite post apocalyptic films.

Mad Max (1979) and Mad Max 2: The Road Warrior (1981)- these were the films that introduced us to an unknown good looking guy from Australia named Mel Gibson. He plays the title character, whose family is killed by a vicious biker gang in a future where gasoline has all but disappeared. The story follows his quest for vengeance. These are the movies that hooked me on this genre.

Escape From New York (1981)- John Carpenter directs Kurt Russell as Snake Pliskin, a condemned criminal and former hero, who is forced to rescue the president when Air Force One is brought down in New York City, which is now a giant prison. Action-filled with a quippy, one-eyed anti-hero in Russell's character.

I Am Legend (2007)- Great book, great movie, great dog! Although the movie has a few differences from the book, I still enjoyed it immensely. As the lone survivor of a virus which turns humans into blood thirsty zombies Will Smith's character, scientist Robert Neville, must battle these creatures with his dog at his side while trying to find a cure.

A Boy and His Dog (1975)- A young Don Johnson communicates telepathically with his dog in a post-nuclear world. He finds a bizarre society underground and must determine if he and his dog are truly safe. Will he fall for the girl (Kathleen Turner) or stick with his dog?

The Road (2009)- I just watched this movie recently, and felt it captured the feeling of the book (which is also excellent) very well. Viggo Mortensen and his son must venture through a post apocalyptic America trying to get to the sea. Starving, attacked by cannibals and searching for other "good guys" the pair form a remarkable father-son bond.

There are so many other good titles in this genre, I want to at least list a few: 28 Days Later, 12 Monkeys (with a startling Brad Pitt), Blade Runner and we must mention, Planet of the Apes (the orignal, of course).


If you've run out of action/adventure films at the movie theatres, try one of these films for your summer movie fix.

entry.title: Adam
entry.content:
The movie "Adam" is somewhat of a romantic comedy and a romantic drama. Adam, the central character, is a reclusive introvert that lives by himself and follows a strict daily routine. You are led to believe that Adam is just a little weird, but otherwise normal. I guess you would think of him as a geek or a nerd without a girlfriend.

At some point a rather attractive woman named Beth moves into the apartment building that Adam lives in and befriends him. They talk, they visit each other and finally begin dating. Adam then tells Beth that he has Asperger's Syndrome. This is what makes the movie worth watching. I don't know how true this is, but I could imagine that dating someone with Asperger's Syndrome could be quite challenging. So will their relationship work out? You'll have to watch the movie to see how it ends.

entry.title: Resistance Movies
entry.content:
Resistance to tyranny and oppression is a theme that resonates throughout history and speaks to our sense of justice and ability to face and oppose evil in the world. Resistance to oppression, whether violent or non-violent, has existed almost since the dawn of humantiy, and this powerful theme lends itself well to cinematic portrayals and interpretations. Some of my favorite movies are based upon the theme of resistance, and I wanted to share some of the titles that we have here in our collection.

Most resistance movies center around World War II and resistance to Nazi persecution of the Jews. Defiance is one of the most recent movies that came out, and it portrays the Bielski brothers as they survived as partisans, along with hundreds of other Jews, in the forest in Belarus. This movie excellently portrays the necessities and reality of life in the forest and as a band of partisans fighting against a real and powerful enemy. There are some very raw moments, but it helps you to see the struggles and reality of partisan warfare, apart from our idealized notion of fighting the "bad guys."

Uprising is a mini series that portrays the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising, which was the Jewish resistance in the Warsaw Ghetto as the Nazis attempted to liquidate it and deport all the Jews living there. This is my favorite resistance movie, and though it is about three hours long, it excellently shows the different aspects of life and resistance in the Jewish ghettos.

Switching gears, there was a British television series in the 1980s entitled 'Allo, 'Allo! that featured a character named Rene Artois who ran a cafe and aided the French resistance during World War II. The show, however, is a comedy and light heartedly addresses (and skewers) the dynamics of French citizens, French resistance, British airmen, and German soldiers in an occupied French town. One of the interesting aspects of the show is how they portray the language differences by using different accents. We have the first two seasons in our collection.

Not all resistance movies focus on World War II, however, and I have included three titles that focus on different aspects of resistance at different points in history and in the world.

The Wind That Shakes the Barley focuses on two brothers who are fighting with the IRA in Ireland during the early 20th century. The movie is raw and rather brutal, but it is a good portrayal of the movement and the sentiments behind it.

Hotel Rwanda is based on a true story of a hotel owner in Rwanda during the Rwandan genocide in 1994 who shelters Tutsis and tries to survive the violence and struggles during this tumultuous and dangerous time in his country. This movie differs from the others listed in that the hotel owner resists non-violently by sheltering people in his hotel and offering them a place of escape. There are not really any battle scenes, but the portrayal of the upheaval, unrest, and danger in the country is very good.

Lastly, Red Dawn is a fictional movie portraying youth in the rural United States fighting against a Communist invasion. This movie is a bit dated, but it still has some entertainment value. It is an interesting idea and look at responding to an invasion.

entry.title: True Romance (1993)
entry.content:
Last night, courtesy of several different Dennis Hopper retrospectives telling me that I should, I watched True Romance. I'm not entirely certain how I managed to get this far without watching that movie before. I love Quentin Tarantino, I love the majority of the cast, I love rapid-fire action, but I just never managed to watch it. So now that I have, let me tell you why you should also watch it.

Let's start with Tarantino. It's kind of odd hearing Tarantino's words spoken by some of his regulars in a movie that doesn't entirely look like something he would make. This movie came out in between Reservoir Dogs and Pulp Fiction and I can't say it really looks like either of them. I can't say it really doesn't either, though. The most striking difference in the delivery of True Romance is the music. I've come to expect a very particular sort of referential song choice from Tarantino. Whether he's bringing back Dusty Springfield or twisting "Stuck in the Middle With You" into something a little bit wrong, Tarantino certainly seems to prefer underground 60s pop and classic ballads. At least, at that point in his career. Hans Zimmer did the score for True Romance and it's a very light, sweet score. Not something I expected to hear when I turned on the movie. That being said, I rather love the way that score contrasts to the violence that surrounds the couple at the heart of the movie.

Let's move on to how the cast makes this movie awesome. I actually think that this, or at least the way the cast was advertised, is the reason I avoided this movie for so long. Between the title, Christian Slater, and some of the movie's posters, I thought it was going to be just another "lovers gone wrong" movie and just skipped it. But it's very much not. They do go wrong, but in the most delightful of fashions. The cast is chockful of Tarantino regulars and completely random awesome people: Patricia Arquette, Dennis Hopper, James Gandolfini, an almost unrecognizable Brad Pitt, Gary Oldman, Samuel L Jackson, Christopher Walken, Kevin Corrigan, a guy who looks like James Urbaniak, but isn't. I got very excited about that last one until I realized it wasn't actually James Urbaniak.

And the final reason you should watch True Romance, "But, you know, I knew something must be rotten in Denmark. There was no way you could like me that much." That's only the first time the "rotten in Denmark" phrase is borrowed in this movie. You should watch True Romance because two separate characters borrow from Hamlet and that is awesome.


You can find True Romance in our catalog!

entry.title: Duplicity
entry.content:
Looking for a good laugh and a movie that has an ending almost impossible to predict? If so you should watch the romantic comedy and spy-thriller Duplicity (2009). The movie begins with two secret agents Claire Steinwick (Julia Roberts) and Ray Cloval (Clive Owens) meeting in Dubai in 2003. Ray is interested in Claire and comes to talk to her, leading to the beginning of a romance. After sleeping together Claire drugs Ray and leaves with top secret documents. The movie then switches to a slow-motion fight without sound between two business men (who turn out to be Burkett & Randles CEO Howard Tully (Tom Wilkinson) and Equikroms CEO Dick Garsik (Paul Giamatti)), setting the stage for a spy game going on between the two companies. The encounters between Claire and Ray continue in the next scene in 2008 in New York City. Ray, who is working for Equikrom, is waiting for an unknown agent from Burkett & Randle, when he bumps into Claire. She pretends not to know him. After a short time both Ray and Claire discover they were waiting for each other and need to work together to complete a spy mission. Thus begins the suspenseful twists and turns of the movie, never letting the viewer know who is spying on whom or who is really in control of the spying game. Along this unknown path you will laugh, be touched by Ray and Claires love, and wait with anticipation for the results of spy missions. At the end you might be shocked, but unlike some other action or spy movies, you can understand how the movie ended the way it did.

By Ania Peczalska

entry.title: Music Twice Over
entry.content:
At home I have an old 16mm film produced around 1964 or 65 called Replay. It opens with a middle aged woman commenting on the youth of the day and their adulation of The Beatles and how much different it was when they were young. The film then proceeds to show screaming teenagers who seem to be tearing at their faces and almost tearing out their hair as they screamed not at The Beatles, but at a young Frank Sinatra; then even older footage of the same reactions to Rudy Vallee. The purpose of the film was to show that things are not really all that different now than they have been in the past.
The film makes a good point, but it isnt the point I want to make. The film has a song sung several times written by someone named Charles Strouse. Some of you might recognize the name. He wrote the musical score for a Tony Award winning play later turned into a movie which Im sure youve heard of, Annie. If you watched my 16mm film you would find yourself possibly humming the tune. Maybe you would be trying to understand why it sounds so familiar. Maybe tomorrow you will figure it out. Maybe the sun will come out tomorrow and give you a flash of insight. After all, tomorrow is only a day away. If you havent figured it out already the tune in "Replay" is the same one he later used for the song Tomorrow. The words may be different, but the tune is the same. We might say that Charles Strouse plagiarized his own work, either intentionally or unintentionally. Its not as uncommon as one might think and movies are a fun place to try to spot them.
Ever hear of Erich Wolfgang Korngold? He wrote the score for two of the most popular films of his time The Sea Hawk and The Adventures of Robin Hood. I suggest you listen to the two soundtracks. I think you will find them very similar. Recently I had the pleasure of watching The Rock with Sean Connery and Nicholas Cage. As I watched the action scenes I found myself tapping my foot to the music. Where have I heard this before? I asked my wife and son who were watching with me. It does sound familiar, my wife responded, sort of like an old swashbuckler. Thats it! I yelled It's the opening theme from the Pirates of the Caribbean. I looked the film credits up in the Internet Movie Data Base and indeed The Rock was scored by Hans Zimmer and the last two Pirates movies were scored by Hans Zimmer. But wait, you say, the opening theme for the first Pirates movie was composed by Klaus Badelt, so he couldnt have reused the music from The Rock. And I would reply, Yes, but the music producer and score arranger for the first Pirates move was none other than Hans Zimmer."
The sound track can make or break a movie and its fun to see if the composers reuse their music. Im not saying you should focus on the music when you watch a movie, but if you like the music take note, you might have heard it somewhere before. If you are looking for the soundtrack to The Rock the library doesnt own it, but if you really liked the music check out the Pirates of the Caribbean soundtracks. It will sound familiar.

entry.title: District 9
entry.content:
I'm not a huge science fiction fan, but I love horror and action flicks and sometimes sci-fi offers aspects of those genres. I read rave reviews for this film and expected a scary, action-filled alien movie. District 9 is much more than that. Filmed documentary-style this movie explores issues other than just the action/adventure that an alien race on Earth might provide. Filled with ideas and questions about humanity the story focuses on an alien settlement in Johannesburg- a ghetto where the aliens who arrived 28 years ago have been separated off from humans. Derisively called "prawns" because of their insect-like features and reviled by humans the aliens are a source of fear and anger. The film follows Wikus van de Merwe a bureaucrat assigned to relocate the aliens. While trying to make a name for himself Wikus becomes actively involved in the military-style relocation process and accidentally sprays some type of alien fluid on himself. Things quickly go downhill for Wikus as he becomes ill and starts to mutate. He is taken into custody by his own company and becomes a fugitive upon his escape. Ironically as Wikus loses his human form he rediscovers his humanity.

Directed by Neill Blomkamp and produced by Peter Jackson District 9 was inspired by events that took place in South Africa during Apartheid in which over 60,000 residents were forcibily removed from "District 6" in Cape Town. This inspiration led to this film, a thinking man's action-thriller which looks at issues including segregation, government control, corporate greed and poverty.
