entry.content:
I have a great love of robots, particularly when they become an exploration of bodies as machines. The new Syfy show Caprica gives us just that. Technically Battlestar Galactica already gave us that with the human form Cylons, but Caprica sees it happen in a more literal sense. It's hard to say more without spoiling the uninitiated, but let's just say the story involves a brilliant computer engineer who has created a holographic gaming world, his equally genius daughter who has hacked his holographic gaming world for her own purposes, and lots and lots of robots.

Here's a completely out-of-context scene from the first season to whet your appetite.


Caprica is much different in tone than Battlestar Galactica, a little soapier than the original show, but I actually found it a more enjoyable viewing experience and I think fans of Battlestar Galactica would enjoy it, if not more, then as much as they did BSG. The cast is amazing, the story is solid, and the robots are awesome. If you feel like giving it a try you can find the pilot episode in our catalog here.

entry.title: That Thing You Do!
entry.content:
Growing up in the sixties I was like many others; my goal in life was to be in a band and make it big like the Beatles. I took drum lessons and my instructor told me to sell my drums and break my sticks. I did better with guitar. I started playing guitar when I was five and Im still playing. In high school I played in several bands hoping to be discovered. We never were discovered and to be honest none of our songs were really very good. But that dream of glory is one reason why That Thing You Do! has become one of my favorite movies.
That Thing You Do! tells the story of local band, The Wonders, that makes it big when a temporary drummer accidently starts one of the bands songs much faster than its writer wrote it. The song becomes an instant smash each time it is played, passed from a local manager to Playtone Records. The Wonders move from small local gigs to touring with the Playtone Galaxy of Stars managed by Tom Hanks (the film's writer and producer). The band features the acting talents of Johathon Schaech as Jimmy, Steve Zahn as Lenny, Ethan Embry as T.B. Player (The Bass Player) and features Tom Everett Scott as Guy, the drummer that takes them to the top. And I cant leave out Liv Tyler, Jimmys girlfriend and the band's wardrobe mistress when they hit the road.
Tom Hanks manages to do something remarkable with this film. He recreates musically the feeling of the early 60s without using one song from the time period. Every song features a style that anyone growing up in the 60's would recognize, but never has heard before. This is the second reason this has become one of my favorite movies. I love the sound track. Yes, this film was made a while ago and Im sure that youve had plenty of chances to see it. But if you havent, check it out.
By the way, I didnt sell my drums and I enjoy playing drums more than I like the guitar, but I still cant play and should likely follow my old instructors advice. Maybe thats a third reason I like this movie. I like seeing a drummer do good.

entry.title: Young Victoria
entry.content:
May 24th is Victoria Day in Canada honoring Britain's longest reigning monarch Queen Victoria who was on the throne from 1837 to 1901. If you think of Queen Victoria at all, you probably picture an elderly woman, dressed in black with a somber expression on her face. As with most people, she did not start out that way. Young Victoria covers her life at the beginning of her reign. She was very young, just 19 years old, when she ascended the throne and had lead a very sheltered life. As with most teenagers, she was anxious to break free and control her own life, while at the same time accepting the responsibilities she had inherited.


The movie looks at Victoria and Albert as a young unmarried couple, with Albert in Germany, not knowing where he stood and Victoria in England working the politics of a royal engagement. After marriage Victoria became devoted to Albert, producing nine children over their 21 year marriage.


Young Victoria brings this 19th century power couple to life by grand sets, on location settings and beautiful costumes, winning the Oscar for costume design. Emily Blunt as Victoria and Rupert Friend as Albert are convincing as young adults beginning their lives together. When Victoria loses her temper with Albert and plays the "I am your queen" card, he simply turns and walks out, leaving her to wonder if she has gone too far.


Rated PG for some language, Young Victoria is a good choice for history lovers, romance lovers and costume designers. The movie is also suitable for young adult viewers.


To learn more about Victoria and Albert, try these books:

Queen Victoria by Lytton Strachey

We Two: Victoria and Albert, rulers, partners, rivals by Gillian Gill

Victoria and Albert by Richard Hough

Uncrowned King: the Life of Prince Albert by Stanley Weintraub

entry.title: The Wages
entry.content:
Officially, The Reverend Peyton's Big Damn Band falls into the "rural blues" genre. A more vivid description might cast their sound as a thick mixture of blues, country, punk and bluegrass stirred up, dipped in batter, fried in pork fat and served family style. In short, an Indiana band that Hoosiers can be proud of.

The Big Damn Band is lead by vocalist and fingerstyle/slide guitarist The Reverend Peyton. His wife, Breezy Peyton, is the intensely percussive washboard player and Aaron "Cuz" Persinger, the most recent addition to the band (replacing the Rev's brother Jamie), is the energetic drummer. While numerically small they succeed in producing a very, very big sound. The Big Damn Band's latest offering - The Wages -is perhaps their most impressive work to date, and, true to the album artwork, a real barnburner.

The albumn's first single "Clap Your Hands" is a fun, upbeat party song. The video, shot in a barn in Southern Indiana, does a lot to illustrate the Band's wide appeal, as well as the wild atmosphere at their live shows. Other diverse and notable songs include the murder ballad "Lick Creek Road," the unrequited lovesong "Sure Feels Like Rain," the frustrated workingman's stomper "Everything's Raising" and the comical "Ft. Wayne Zoo" in which the Reverend tells of his brother's act of poultry thievery. Singer/songwriter/accordionist Jason Webley is the guest of honor on "Two Bottles of Wine" - a song that does a great job of capturing the BDB's powerful stage presence.

Indiana natives in particular will find a lot to like about not only "Lick Creek Road," and "Ft. Wayne Zoo," but also "Sugar Creek," "What Go Around Come Around," and "Born Bred, Corn Fed." The Wages is a celebration of midwestern, especially Hoosier, life and values. Yet the aesthetic is rustic and simple, and distinctly non-ideological. The lyrical expressions of frustration and joy are human - not political - and it is easy to see how the Big Damn Band attracts such a diverse set of fans.

MCPL also has copies of the Big Damn Band's earlier albums - Big Damn Nation and The Whole Fam Damnily - as well as The Gospel Album, and all are highly recommeded by this reviewer.

The Big Damn Band has been touring relentlessly and has cultivated fans all over the country and, the Icelandic ash cloud notwithstanding, all over the world as well. Fortunately, as Brown County natives these folks come back to Southern Indiana to roost. They'll be playing a free, all-ages set at Landlocked Records on Saturday, June 12th to promote The Wages and hitting the stage at the Bluebird that evening before joining the Van's Warped Tour this summer.

Check these folks out. You won't regret it.

entry.title: "...a song that was a hit before your Mother was born."
entry.content:
I once built a time-machine. I started with a 1950 Chevrolet 3/4 ton pickup truck. Converted it to a 12 volt electrical system, added a cassette tape player and all I had to do is pop in some Hank Williams. Voila, there I was bouncing down a two lane highway and singing along to "Kawliga". It wasn't perfect but it was darned close.
That was back in 1978 or '79 and little did I know then that in just 30 more years I could come even closer with "Hank Williams : The Unreleased Recordings". This is a box set of 54 songs and studio chatter from Hank's "Mother's Best Flour" radio show.
Back in the early 1950's Hank was contracted to do a daily15 minute radio spot on WSM in Nashville at 7:00 AM. When he knew he would be on the road they would pre-record shows on acetate discs to be played at the appropriate time. Generally programs like this would be discarded after the play date but Hank's shows were kept at the station and rediscovered in the 1970's. They were eventually given to Hank's daughter Jett and the inevitable long legal battle ensued. But we now have for the first time 54 songs along with some studio chatter restored and released by Time-Life records. The box set is a mix of hit tunes, hymns and songs that were not recorded and released at the time. I wish I still had that old Chevy.

entry.title: The African Queen
entry.content:
Charlie Allnut: Howd you like it?
Rose Sayer: Like it?
Charlie Allnut: Whitewater rapids!
Rose Sayer: I never dreamed
Charlie Allnut: I dont blame you for being scared not one bit. Nobody with good sense aint scared of whitewater.
Rose Sayer: I never dreamed that any mere physical experience could be so stimulating!

So goes the conversation aboard the African Queen, a small riverboat, at first escaping from the Germans in Africa during WWI , but in the end setting downriver to destroy the German gunboat Louisa. This would be a difficult voyage for any crew; portions of the river are almost impassable. But in truth there is no crew, only the owner of the boat Charlie Allnut [Humphrey Bogart] and Rose Sayer [Katherine Hepburn] the straight-laced sister of a recently deceased missionary.

There have been many movies that focused on the relationship between two opposites. But The African Queen sets the bar higher than almost any other. There is chemistry between Bogart and Hepburn that works like few other pairings. You can see the barriers that separate them crumble as they go through one trial after another. The film is about more than adventure. It is about a battle of wills, love, and desperation.

The DVD of The African Queen has been long awaited. Prior to the most recent release the only copies available were taken from poor quality prints. Even the official Republic Pictures release of the movie on VHS was marred by fading and/or damaged film stock. Finally, this classic movie has been lovingly restored and re-issued. If you like a film with a good story, good acting and good characters dont miss the seeing The African Queen.

entry.title: My Flesh and Blood
entry.content:
This 2003 documentary focuses on single mother Susan Tom, who has adopted 11 special needs children. Winner of the Audience and Director's Awards at the Sundance Film Festival My Flesh and Blood follows this fascinating family for a year. Susan provides her children with the necessities of life (with limited help from the state), love and acceptance, and tries to provide them with the most normal childhoods they can have. Her brood includes two girls born without legs, an 8-year-old with a disfigured face, and a difficult 15-year-old boy suffering from servere ADD, cystic fibrosis, and anger issues. Included in the mix are Susan's two biological children- living on their own, and her adopted daughter Magaret, a college student with no special needs who struggles within the chaos of her home. The film captures this unique family with an unsentimental eye, making the story both uplifting and touching. Susan finds ways to create laughter and fun for children who have many strikes against them. She encourages them to live life to the fullest and refuses to focus on their limitations. This fascinating film can't help but leave viewers with a new appreciation for their own lives.
As a footnote the family was featured on Extreme Makeover: Home Edition in the summer of 2005. Click the link to see their home.

entry.title: "...a song that was a hit before your mother was born."
entry.content:
For more than fifty years music lovers have been paraphrasing the old Superman chestnut--"It's a bird. It's a plane." With Mose Allison they've been yelling --He's a Jazz man. He's a Blues man. And both sides are right. Mose is one jazzy blues man and a helluva bluesy jazz man.

It's been 12 years since Mose Allison released an album. He was 70 years old when he produced "Gimcracks and Gewgaws" and I thought... what a great album to cap off a great career. But here he is at 82 and just as bluesy, jazzy and ironic as ever. Very few artists can boast of such a consistent output as Mose. He recorded his first album "Back Country Suite" in 1957 and more than 30 albums since then. If you like good jazz-- you'll like Mose. If you like good blues--you'll like Mose. If you like songs written with great hooks and drenched in irony--you'll like Mose. If you like music--you'll like Mose.
Check it out.

entry.title: The Lookout
entry.content:
The Lookout is a little-known gem starring Joseph Gordon-Levitt (who appeared on Third Rock from the Sun as a child) as Chris, a young man with a once-promising future who is now brain damaged. His own recklessness caused the accident which injured him and killed two of his friends. His future is bleak as his short-term memory is nearly shot, limiting what he is able to achieve. He lives with a friend who is blind (Jeff Daniels) and he works as a janitor at a bank. Chris is lonely and frustrated in his current circumstances and easily falls prey to a gang of bank robbers who befriend him to use him in their scheme. But as the plan moves forward he begins to have second thoughts.

Writen and directed by Scott Frank, who skillfully adapted Elmore Leonard's Get Shorty and Out of Sight for the screen, this twisty thriller also boasts strongly developed characters. The acting alone by the excellent cast makes this a film worth watching, but the suspenseful plot pulls the viewer in. If you enjoy Gordon-Levitt's performance in this film you may want to check him out in two others in which his acting is as good, if not better: Mysterious Skin and Brick.

entry.title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant
entry.content:
Finally, a modern vampire film where the vampires are not love forsaken angst-filled teenagers or shapeless monsters. Well, ok there are some angst-filled teenagers, but they are more the Peter Parker type; not quite nerds, but not the most popular kids in school either. They are just normal kids who end up in an unusual situation. This is another of those films that I was prepared not to like and ended up loving.
Based on a series of books by Darren Shan, Cirque du Freak tells the story of two boys Darren Shan (yes, the character has the same name as the author of the books) and Steve. The first loves spiders, but not in a weird freaky way. He just finds them interesting. The second is obsessed with vampires. His hearts desire is to find out they are real and to become one. He hasnt had a happy home life. Both attend the Cirque du Freak, a modern freak show, and meet headliner Larten Crepsley who is a sort of curmudgeon vampire with a trained poisonous spider. Crepsleys main goal is to avoid a war with the Vampenezee. The difference between the vampires and the Vampenezee is that vampires dont kill their victims and the Vampenezee do. There are a lot of other differences in vampire lore which are poked fun at. The film is both fun and exciting with its tongue firmly planted in its cheek. There are little side jokes that really arent that funny, but become funny because of the excellent casting. John C. Reilly is perfect as Larten Crepsley. Chris Massoglia plays Darren and somehow manages to remind me of Ralph Macchio from Crossroads and The Karate Kid though Im not really sure why. I dont want to spoil the story by telling you more. The fun is in the story and getting there is like going through a fun house for the first time.
My final word: Cirque du Freak: The Vampires Assistant is not a great film, but its fun and made me laugh. The special effects are good without being distracting and it is different enough to be enjoyable. It is open for a sequel and I hope they make it. In the meantime, Im going to have to read the books.

entry.title: Quarantine
entry.content:
I love horror films, but after years of watching them it's difficult to find films that are original, truly scary and compelling. Quarantine , released in 2008, offers all this and more. The film starts out with a simple premise. A news reporter (Jennifer Carpenter from the wonderful Showtime series Dexter ) and her cameraman film segments following people who work at night, focusing this time on a fire department. Eventually they are called out to an apartment building. Upon arrival the team quickly discovers this is anything but a typical call. When they enter a woman's apartment to see what is wrong with her she is standing zombie-like and is unresponsive, then viciously attacks those who are trying to help her. Suffice to say things quickly go downhill. The apartment is soon sealed off by the CDC and anyone who tries to escape is shot.

Filmed from the perspective of the cameraman the audience is pulled directly into the situation, causing the viewer feel the paranoia and claustrophobia of those trapped in the building cut off from all outside communication. Quarantine is high on the violence and gore scales, and is definitely not for those with a weak stomach. But for horror afficionados this movie delivers some real scares and one of the creepiest endings I've seen.

entry.title: "...a song that was a hit before your mother was born."
entry.content:
Here we are barely into 2010 and I already have a favorite CD. Once again I have fallen for a young group doing old music. The group is the "Carolina Chocolate Drops". The CD is Genuine Negro Jig. The provocatively named Carolina Chocolate Drops are three young, African-American multi-instrumentalists from North Carolina who named their band in honor of the Tennessee Chocolate Drops, a black string band from the 1930's.
The Chocolate Drops consist of Dom Flemons, Rhiannon Giddins and Justin Robinson. These young people first got together at the 2005 Black Banjo Gathering in Asheville, NC to explore the neglected tradition of black string band music. They found a willing mentor in 90-year-old Joe Thompson, acknowledged to be one of the last old-time black fiddle players. However, in the last 5 years the CCD have branched out into blues, folk, old Vaudeville tunes and even hip-hop. That is the mix on this new album.

The title track is from a transcription found in the papers of Daniel Decatur Emmett (1815-1904), a founder of the minstrel show tradition and a neighbor of the Snowdens, a black family who lived in Clinton, Ohio. The Snowdens were a well-known musical family, composing and performing original music throughout the Midwest. Along with the fiddle tune on the album, there are good arguments for crediting them with the song "Dixie." Along with "Snowden's Jig" are six more traditional tunes: "Peace Behind the Bridge," "Trouble in Your Mind," "Cornbread and Butterbeans," "Cindy Gal," "Sandy Boys" and an accapella rendition of the old English ballad "Reynadine." But then the album comes up with some serious surprises.

One of those surprises is a jazz-blues song made famous by Peggy Lee, "Why Don't You Do Right" sung by Rhiannon, who makes it her own. Another is Justin's take on the Tom Wait's song "Trampled Rose" and his own composition, "Kissin' and Cussin'." All in all, I have to say that this is one of the most pleasing albums I have heard in a long time.
Check it out--I think you'll agree

entry.title: Goo goo for Gaga!
entry.content:
What is it that they say about nonconformists? In their refusal to conform they are actually conforming? Well, call me what you will, maybe I am a sellout but I love Lady Gaga. After working my way from number 35 on the hold list it was finally my turn! I could hardly wait to get into my car after work and put the CD in the stereo. Let's just say it was a fun ride home.

Lady Gaga's second studio release, The Fame Monster, does not stray too far from her beat-heavy first album The Fame. The listener is instantly taken to the dance floor, a reminder of Gaga's roots in the New York City club scene. With only 8 tracks and lasting a little over 30 minutes The Fame Monster is a quick listen, though the songs themselves are a little longer than the standard two or three minutes. At first it would seem that Lady Gaga doesn't write songs about much other than partying in the club, drinking champagne, and boy trouble but this album delves to a much darker side of fame and fortune. Though she touched on America's obsession with pop culture with her single "Paparazzi" on the first album, this album employs a monster metaphor for the subject of fame. One gets the feeling that the monster that ate Gaga's heart on the track "Monster" is more than just one boy, and could be the music and entertainment industry as a whole. Everyone wants a piece of Gaga, as the songs "Alejandro" and "Telephone" profess. In "Alejandro," Gaga bemoans the unwanted attention of Alejandro, Fernando, and Roberto, while in "Telephone" she just wants her phone to stop ringing so she can dancedancedance. Real concerns for any socialite, I'm sure.

Probably the best thing about The Fame Monster release is that deluxe editions of the album also include the first album. This way listeners can become familiar with some of Lady Gaga's other music, which is just as fun and fabulous (if not more so!) If you are looking for something fun to dance to or just to get you out of a music rut look no further, Lady Gaga has got what you need. entry.title: For Love of Liberty
entry.content: Yesterday I watched For Love of Liberty. Its a great film for any discussion group and especially for Black History Month. This is a documentary film that follows the lives of African American men and women in the United States Military since the mid 1700s. I had no idea that so many African Americans participated in the Revolutionary War and the War of 1812. While I had heard of Crispus Attucks, I had assumed that African Americans were largely silent during the Revolutionary War. The documentary goes on to highlight the service of African Americans in the Civil War, World War I, World War II, the Korean War, Vietnam and of course Iraq and Afghanistan. Made in 2010 and totaling over 240 minutes, Im sure you history buffs will find something that you didnt know. We have this new DVD in our collection and you can check its status by clicking here.

entry.title: Get in Touch with your "Emotionalism"
entry.content:
In the past few months I have rekindled my love of country and bluegrass music. I generally don't stray too far beyond my old favorites: Johnny Cash, Steve Earle, Hank Williams (and his grandson Hank III!), Dwight Yoakam, and Loretta Lynn to name a few. This past summer a friend living in South Carolina introduced me to one of his favorite musical acts, The Avett Brothers. I had heard about these guys before but had never paid enough attention to know what they sounded like. My first taste was a video he sent of the group crammed into the Jackson Hole gondola with an upright bass, a snare drum, and a guitar. What were these mournful yet lively, twangy, and raw harmonies gracing my ears? I was hooked.

Comprised of talented brothers Scott and Seth Avett, plus their bassist Bob Crawford, The Avett Brothers formed in 2001 in Charlotte, North Carolina. Since then they have developed quite a following, with sold out shows all over the U.S. and 13 full-length and EP albums released, their most recent in 2009 entitled I and Love and You.

The first album I had the pleasure of listening to in its entirety, and the subject of this review, was Emotionalism, released in 2007. From the first track to the last I marveled at the huge sound that could be created by three people. Not to mention that this sound combines something old and something new to become something all its own. The artists clearly draw from influences like Neil Young, Ramblin Jack Elliott and others but combine them with their refreshingly original lyrics framed by aching minor chords. The sometimes nasal, sometimes falsetto, but always lovely voices of the brothers meld perfectly with their banjo plucking and percussion. You might even hear some average household objects in the background being used to make music as well. The entire album is a gem, but some tracks that particularly sparkled were: "Die Die Die," "I Would Be Sad," and probably my favorite "Pretty Girl From Chile" which laments the mistreatment of Chilean Gabriela, includes an answering machine message from supposed Gabriela, and then breaks into a heavy metal jam for a couple of minutes...surely symbolic of a broken heart/ego. Really, I just love this album and I think if you check it out you'll soon love it too!

entry.title: Rustler's Rhapsody
entry.content:
Who can forget the classic westerns of the past? You could always spot the good guy; he wore a white hat, never got dirty and never killed a man. He simply shot the villains gun out of his hand and he never missed. The good guy was pure, in love with his horse and was just as good with a guitar as he was with a gun.
Around the late sixties the classic western began to disappear. It was replaced with a version that was darker. It became harder to tell the heroes from the villains. Rustlers Rhapsody is a comedy that takes the hero from the classic western and puts him in the confusing world of the westerns of the 80s, a time when Clint Eastwood defined the genre and the cowboy had stopped singing and started shooting. While not quite as funny as Mel Brooks Blazing Saddles, Rustlers Rhapsody is still worth a look.
Tom Berenger stars as good guy Rex OHerlihan, a root eating, guitar playing, hand shooting, horse kissing hero of the old West. He is almost perfect as the now confused hero trying to adapt to a new western, while trying to maintain the morals of the old western. The acting is all over-the-top, with stars like Andy Griffith, who plays the villain (?) with gusto in a parody of both western time periods. Why the question mark? Because in this world it is not as clear which side is the wrong side. For anyone who grew up watching Roy Rogers, The Lone Ranger, Gene Autry and others there are lots of situations that are just left or right of familiar. And the final shoot-out is one of the best and funniest Ive ever seen.

entry.title: "...a song that was a hit before your mother was born."
entry.content:
Although this album, Geoff Muldaur and the Texas Sheiks, was released in September of 2009 the songs on it are a tasty collection of pre-WWII blues, rags, western swing and jug band tunes. Geoff Muldaur, who honed his chops with the "Jim Kweskin Jug Band" back in the 1960s, heads up this roots music supergroup. Muldaur takes the vocals, guitar and banjo duties, assisted by Cindy Cashdollar on dobro and National steel guitars. The woman behind the incredible fiddle work is Suzy Thompson. Bruce Hughes keeps everything together with the upright bass. Texas bluesman Johnny Nicholas does duty on vocals, guitar, harmonica, mandolin, 6 string banjo, kick drum and backup vocals. Song writer Stephen Bruton, to whom the album is dedicated, adds guitar, mando and 6 string banjo licks. And showing up on various cuts are guests Jim Kweskin, vocals and guitar, Floyd Domino on piano and Damien Llanes playing brushes. All in all, this is one of the tightest, togetherest groups I have ever heard. They play hard but laid-back, loose and precise all at the same time.

The songs run the gamut of traditional blues like the first cut, "The World is Going Wrong" and "Poor Boy" to the old Vaudeville chestnut, "Under the Chicken Tree" and the Frankie Jaxson's hokum song, "Fan It". The tempo changes with a dead on version of Skip James' "Hard Times Killin' Floor Blues" and Robert Johnson's haunting, "Travelin' Riverside." There's not a bad cut in the whole mess.

This is without a doubt the very best acoustic album of 2009. Give it a listen.

entry.title: Monkey Business
entry.content:
The opening for Monkey Business starts with a close up of an open door over which the opening credits are placed. While the credits are running the door opens, a man appears, and a voiceover says, Not yet Cary. There is a brief confused nod and the door closes again. This pretty much sets the tone for the film- a no holds barred (for the time) screwball comedy starring Cary Grant, Ginger Rogers and Marilyn Monroe.
Directed by Howard Hawks, Monkey Business tells the story of mild mannered research chemist Barnaby Fulton (Cary Grant) who is working on a formula for a new vitamin. Instead he accidently discovers a fountain of youth. It not only rejuvenates the body, but the mind as well, taking the thought processes back anywhere from that of young man to a small child, depending on the dose. The formula is accidently taken by both Barnaby and his wife Edwina (Ginger Rogers) with the result that they regress in behavior from middle aged adults to small children. Add to this mix a secretary (Marilyn Monroe) with a secret crush on Barnaby and you have a formula for one laugh after another. There is a reason for the title, but youll just have to find out what it is for yourself.
You might be tempted to bypass this film because it is old (1952) and in black and white, but dont. This film is honestly one of my favorites and one I watch any time I need a good laugh. Its family friendly and well worth seeing. If you like a good comedy this is one to see.
My Final Word: Monkey Business, just good clean fun.

entry.title: Mongolian Ping Pong
entry.content:
Warning: not a lot happens in Ning Hao's Mongolian Ping Pong.

A 7 year old boy, Bilike, living on the Mongolian steppe finds a ping pong ball floating down the river. He has no idea what it is and his slightly batty grandmother tells him is is a glowing pearl, sent by the river spirits. As Bilike and his friends slowly figure out what the ball is (in a truly funny scene involving a homemade tv antenna), the confusion actually grows.
The cinamatography of this movie is beautifully stunning. Bilike and his friends spend a lot of time riding around Inner Mongolia on their horses (though one friend rides a gas powered scooter - you never know really why) and the scenery is amazing. This movie was made with locals, not professional actors. They aren't polished and slick but instead subtle and genuine. At the core, it is a coming of age story true to its time and place. The movie never feels forced and slowly pulls you in.
I won't give it away, but the final scene is so unexpected, I didn't know whether to laugh or cry!

entry.title: Two films you might have missed this year...
entry.content:
Based on the best-selling book from an investigative journalist in Italy, Gomorrah tells the story of a variety of characters within the circle of the Naples Mafia. The film serves as an expose of the myriad of illegal business ventures involving all members of the crime syndicate. The characters engage in the illegal dumping of toxic waste, sweat shops manufacturing international clothing brands, and of course drugs. A majority of the cast members have no previous training as actors and actually came from the area in which the film is located. The lack of embellished performances enhances the films authenticity. Also the film does not function as a sensationalized polemic against the mafia, but instead provides a blunt and visceral depiction that is jarring in its frankness. Characters are broken, exploited, and killed with an almost seemingly matter-of-fact style, simply to illustrate this is how this world functions. It's bleakness may sound off-putting to some, but this layered and masterfully constructed tale artfully details the world of a group many of us in America are entirely ignorant of. You can place a hold on the film by clicking here.



Another little known and endearing film comes from a country, many of us only know from Sacha Baran Cohen's Borat. The film Tulpan comes from Kazakhstan and tells the story of Asa, a young man who has just finished his naval service and who wishes to marry a local girl. She however does not wish to marry Asa, who she points out has rather large ears. Currently Asa resides with his sister and brother-in-law in a desolate and barren land covered with sand. His brother-in-law is a shepard and one day Asa hopes to be one as well. His awkwardness and naivety makes this seem impossible, however he is definitely determined. What might seem saccharine as first, turns out to be incredibly charming film, with an almost documentary approach to herding and life in such an extreme setting. Overall, the subtly of the performances and the minimalist approach to the dialogue and the scenes enhance the film's naturalist tone. The film's appeal is also strengthened by how alive and important the animals are as characters in the film. You can place a hold on the film by clicking here.

entry.title: The Lobotomist
entry.content:
Since I was a small child I had heard about lobotomies but I never really knew what they were. All I knew was that it had something to do with the front of the brain and it was something that you really didnt want to have done to you. The PBS documentary The Lobotomist gave me the answers. However it did more than this- it explained the reason why, for awhile at least, it seemed like a miracle cure for mental illness, and it explained how it moved from a medical miracle to a barbarous practice."
Lobotomy was pioneered by neurologist Walter Freeman and like the practice he went from savior to moral monster. This documentary takes a hard look at the practice and man behind it. Was he really an insane moral monster or a man who truly believed he was helping the people he worked on? There were indeed people who were helped by having a lobotomy, though they were far outnumbered by the failures. I found the documentary both fascinating and scary. Not simply because of the results although in history we have had medical experiments that yielded results just as horrendous, but because Freeman managed to make lobotomy simple. So simple in fact that after viewing the documentary I knew that I could in fact perform a lobotomy at home with items found easily in my house. Freeman had taken what I had pictured as a major operation into an assembly line process, and in fact once performed over 25 lobotomies in one day.
My Final Word: The Lobotomist provides a look at the medical process and how what can seem of value one day can turn out to be the horror of tomorrow.

entry.title: In Bruges-A Dark Comedy
entry.content:
In Bruges will run you through the emotional gamut and dump you out on the other side wondering what just happened. This 2008 Sundance Film Festival opener is a pleasant change from the action-packed blockbusters and happy-go-lucky chick flicks that seem so prevalent these days.

This decidedly dark comedy portrays two hitmen hiding out in the fairy tale city of Bruges, Belgium. The hitmen Ray and Ken, played by Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson respectively, are a rough-around-the-edges lot who certainly do not fit in with the serene calm of a city like Bruges. Having killed a child by mistake on his first hit assignment, Ray has been sent into hiding by his boss Harry, a cockney-accented hothead played by Ralph Fiennes. Little does Ray know, but Ken has been sent along to right the wrong of the child's murder by killing him.

Not expecting to find anything worthwhile in Bruges , Ray meets a beautiful Belgian woman named Chloe and goes on a date with her only to discover that she and her boyfriend are planning to rob him. Chloe's boyfriend Erik bursts in on the two in a compromising situation, drawing a gun loaded with blanks on Ray. Ray and Erik struggle, with Ray disarming Erik and shooting him, partially blinding him. A stream of events lead to a shocking denouement and conclusion, but I will keep the details to myself in order to avoid giving away too much.

Making good use of location and maintaining a dark theme throughout, director and writer Martin McDonagh has produced a gem of a film that is as visual as it is cerebral. This is the kind of movie that stays with you long after it is over. Although In Bruges has a steady pace and plenty of action, it also closely focuses on the emotions of the characters. Ray's inability to cope with his guilt over killing the boy, combined with Ken's reluctance to kill Ray make for interesting portrayals of hitmen with consciences. And even as Ray laments his terrible misfortune at being stuck in Bruges, the viewer remains captivated by sweeping shots of cobblestone streets and misty canals. The dialogue is witty and engaging, though the Irish brogue of Ken and Ray may be difficult to interpret at times. Accents aside, the acting in this film is superb, with stellar performances by Farrell (he won a Golden Globe for Best Actor in a Musical or Comedy) and Fiennes. Even the lesser-known actors don't disappoint, and you may find yourself wondering, like I did, why I didn't hear more about this movie when it came out in 2008!

A well-kept secret no longer, add In Bruges to the list of movies you must see in 2010!

entry.title: "...a song that was a hit before your mother was born."
entry.content:
In my last posting I talked a little about the birth of jazz in the early part of the last century but jazz wasnt the only new musical genre to show up at that time. In 1920 Mamie Smith recorded Crazy Blues and while it was not the first blues record (there were instrumental blues going back to 1914) it was the first vocal blues on record. And it captured the record buying publics imagination.


The first wave of the blues craze focused primarily on female blues shouters; notably Ma Rainey and Bessie Smith. Ma Rainey was born Gertrude Pridgett into a family of Minstrel performers in 1886. She married comedy songster William Pa Rainey in 1904 and they toured as Ma and Pa Rainey. It was during this time that she started working blues songs into her act. Ma Rainey separated from Pa in 1916 and continued as a solo performer. With the help of legendary record producer Mayo Ink Williams, Ma recorded Bo-weevil Blues with Lovie Austin and her Blues Serenaders in 1923. Her popularity continued to grow throughout the 1920s and she recorded with many of the great musicians of that era including Louis Armstrong, Coleman Hawkins, Thomas Dorsey, Tampa Red and Fletcher Henderson.

Backing up to 1912, Ma and Pa Rainey were touring with the Moses Stokes troupe that also featured a young woman named Bessie Smith. Bessie, who was a dancer at the time, was befriended by Ma Rainey and undoubtedly picked up on Mas performing technique. Bessie dropped dancing and took up the blues sometime after that and by the 1920s she was almost as popular a recording star as her mentor. By the mid 20s she was the highest paid black entertainer in America.

Bessie Smith set standards for feeling and delivery that blues singers still strive to emulate today. She cut 160 records for Columbia working with Louis Armstrong, James P. Johnson and Fletcher Henderson. Columbias PR office dubbed her the Queen of the Blues but she has since been up-graded to Empress. Her recording career continued until the dark days of the early 1930s when blues were giving way to swing music. Bessie continued to perform and tour and was working on a transformation to swing music. However, in 1937, before she could make a comeback she was killed in an automobile accident.

Listening to Ma Rainey, the Mother of the Blues and Bessie Smith, the Empress of the Blues is a musical time trip worth taking to understand the early days of American music and popular culture.

entry.title: Lobster Tale
entry.content:
A Lobster Tale starring Colm Meaney has nothing really to do with lobsters and everything to do with people. I almost missed watching this family movie. Had I not been home sick with nothing to watch when it came on TV I would have missed it. Im glad I didnt. This is a family movie about values that somehow manages to miss the pitfalls of many family movies.

Colm plays a simple down on his luck New England lobsterman name Cody who finds a strange and slightly glowing seaweed in one of his traps. Never having seen this before he places it in an old coffee can. Shortly after his discovery he accidently cuts off a finger; looking for anything to dull the pain he thrusts his finger into the seaweed and suddenly his finger and hand are reunited whole. The amount of seaweed he has available is limited and word gets out that Cody has a magical weed that will heal anything.

The story has a chance to get hokey and sappy but somehow manages to avoid doing so because it revolves not just around the town asking Cody for healing for their various real and imagined aliments, but on the simple wants and desires of Cody and his family. The focus is not so much on the healing weed as on the people and what they think is important in life. There are several subplots going on at once and I wont tell you about them because they are part of what keeps the film moving. The characters play at the edge of stereotypes but never seem to fall into them. They seem real and down to earth. They are the type of people who you might like to meet and spend some time with.

My final word: Lobster Tale is a good film for the whole family. One that might make you think, might make you sad, might make you happy, but wont disappoint.

entry.title: A Classic Album for All Seasons
entry.content:
Most people I talk to have some sort of strong connection to Jeff Buckley's sole album Grace. Son of musician Tim Buckley, Jeff began to enjoy popularity in the early 90's playing covers in Manhattan bars. After managing to sign a record deal with Columbia, he was able to form a band and record Grace, his only studio album.

Since his tragic drowning death in 1997, Buckley has enjoyed a cult following with several posthumous releases of his material. Likely best renowned for its version of Leonard Cohen's "Hallelujah," the album Grace is an achingly heartfelt recording with songs of staggering beauty. The heavy rock sound of guitars and drums are juxtaposed nicely with Buckley's mournful falsetto. His is a music of love, longing, and a certain rawness that pulls the listener in like a warm embrace. With the first track "Mojo Pin," Grace starts off with a hard edge, heavy on electric guitar riffs and drums and then manages to meld seamlessly to softer tracks like "Lilac Wine" and "Lover, You Should've Come Over."

Listening to Grace is the best way to get acquainted with Buckley's sound, and once you fall in love with the album you will inevitably want to listen to more and will lament the fact that it is the only full-length studio album produced. Diehards will be pleased to know that a collection of demo recordings and a full-length album being reworked by Buckley before his death were released in 1998 as Sketches for My Sweetheart the Drunk.

It might be hard to come to terms with the fact that there will never be another album like Grace from such a magnificent mind as Buckley's. However, the sheer genius of the music left behind offers a glimpse into the life of a thoughtful, poetic man unfairly cut short in his musical prime.

entry.title: Yelle-Pop Up
entry.content:
It was love at first listen...


Pop-Up is the first album from French electro-pop group Yelle, and from the first bass-pumping track, "Ce jeu," to the synth-pop sound of "Tristesse/Joie," and the sultry poutiness of "Tu es beau" it is non-stop fun. For all you dance music lovers, this is the hard-hitting, energetic sound that makes you want to get on your feet and move.


Released in 2007 and reaching #61 on the French Top 100 Albums Chart, Yelle has garnered itself an international fanbase. The group consists of three members: GrandMarnier- responsible for production and writing, Yelle-cowriting and interpretation (main vocals), and Tepr: co-production. It is hard to believe that such a big sound could come from three members, however Yelle manages to create music that fills any space with its heavy beats and catchy lyrics sung in Yelle's sweet voice. Though all of the songs are sung/rapped in French, this album is still very accessible to listeners. You do not need to know the literal translation of "A cause des garcons," but once you hear Yelle's terse and no-nonsense chorus, the meaning "Because of boys" doesn't seem too hard to believe.


What I love about this album is that it keeps its energy up for the duration of the disc. The artists stay true to the mood and the mission: to make music that makes you want to dance! This is the type of CD you put on at a lively party, or maybe even when you're cleaning the house and need something to keep rhythm to. It is just downright fun music that never takes itself too seriously and is sure to bring some liveliness to your music library.


Give Pop Up a listen and see what all the fuss is about.

entry.title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son about his Father
entry.content:
I came across this compelling documentary by chance and cannot recommend it highly enough. The film was done by Kurt Kuenne, a filmaker, who set out to memorialize his murdered friend for the victim's son. The story itself is fascinating enough- a medical student, Andrew Bagby, is murdered by his ex-girlfriend. She immediately flees the US for her homeland of Canada and announces she is pregnant with Andrew's child. Dear Zachary starts as a film depicting an ordinary man who found himself in an increasingly bizarre situation. Kuenne presents a portrait of Bagby through remembrances of friends and family so that his child will have the chance to know the father he never met. But the documentary becomes even more fasincating as Andrew's parents' search for justice in the confusing Canadian legal system and fight for custody of their grandson. Frequently they are allowed to see Zachary only at the will of their son's murderer. The travesty of justice the family experiences in Canada is horrifying, as is the fact that they are forced to deal with their son's killer in order to have a relationship with Zachary.

This is a heartbreaking documentary that does not tell a happy story. Bagby's parents are the real heroes here, with their endless stamina and strength facing nearly incredible odds that is both sad and inspiring to see. As a result of their experiences they have become advocates for bail reform in Canada. The film not only tells a compelling story, but is a finely crafted documentary. The editing effortlessly interweaves Andrew Bagby's past with present events. This documentary has won numerous awards, including being named one of the top five documentaries of 2008 by the National Board of Review. Although not always an easy film to watch, this is definitely worth your time.

entry.title: Star Trek (2009)
entry.content:
These are the voyages of the Starship Enterprise. Its five year mission There is almost no television show with a more recognizable opening except maybe Jeopardy and the Twilight Zone. But what would happen if some crazed Romulan came back in time and killed the father of James T. Kirk (Chris Pine) just before he was born; the resulting problem child growing up without the presence of his father. How might the legend we have grown up with have changed? Would the well known crew of the Enterprise have met? How would their relationships have differed? These are the questions that this film poses and answers.

Star Trek (2009) is a fresh and more action filled adventure than any shows of the original series were. It even managed to please me and I watched Star Trek faithfully when it was first on in the sixties. Most of the cast seemed to fit their roles very well. With few exceptions I had no problems accepting the new actors in their parts. Far and away the best fit, in my opinion, was Zachary Quinto as Spock. He looks so much like the Spock from the original series that I had to think about it to tell the difference. He even passed the ultimate test for his character at the end of the movie. If youve seen it, you know which one I mean; if you havent seen it I wont spoil it for you.

Director JJ Abrams has created a new feel to an old established show; one that should please even the most diehard fans. Are there differences from the cannon of the old series? Of course there are and you can nitpick all you want about them, but they can all be explained away with but its a different timeline. I really loved this movie and I didnt expect to. It was filled with fun inside references to the original series and you know that somehow, someway the old gang is going to get back together with enough differences to make it interesting. I really hope they continue making films with these actors and in this time line. It was great to see my old friends again.

My final word: Its Star Trek. Its fun. Its different and familiar all at the same time.

entry.title: A Hard Life
entry.content: This is a documentary film about the struggles of three local residents living in Bloomington as they cope with living through hard times. One person lost her home during the flood last year. Another person was pregnant and lost her job. The third person was laid off and slipped into poverty after the recession. This documentary is in part about the lives of these three individuals and the unique social services that Bloomington and Monroe County provides to help people in these situations. It is a compelling story. If you are interested in understanding the issues that surround poverty, then this is the film for you. The library has this film in our collection. You can check it's status here.

entry.title: Rachel Getting Married
entry.content: This film, directed by Jonathan Demme, stars Anne Hathaway in a brave departure from her usual sunny characters. She portrays Kym, a recovering addict who takes a short leave from rehab to return to her childhood home for her sister's wedding. Kym has had a long history of substance abuse, which has caused estrangement from her family. They greet her visit with mixed emotions. As the weekend plays out family secrets come to light, which explain some of Kym's problems and much of the family's reactions to her. Hathaway portrays Kym unflinchingly as a self-absorbed addict who expects her family to be understanding, forgiving, and completely focused on her and her issues. Her sister has nearly reached the end of her rope in dealing with Kym, especially during a weekend that should focus on her impending marriage. This movie is filled with great perfomances, especially by Hathaway, who gives us an unlikeable character that we can sympathize with. I enjoyed the story of the family dynamics, but found the sequences depicting the rehearsal dinner, the wedding party, and the musicians a bit lengthy. I also found the quirkiness of the wedding itself a bit forced. But despite these shortcomings Rachel Getting Married is a movie worth watching to see some excellent performances and an interesting story of a dysfunctional family.

entry.title: Dogtown: Second Chances
entry.content:
Dogtown: Second Chances is an episode of the National Geographic series focusing on an area of the Best Friends Animal Sanctuary in Utah which houses, of course, dogs. The non-profit, no kill sanctuary houses all types of animals and tries to find homes for them all, but some stay throughout their lives due to health or behavioral issues. This fascinating look at Dogtown follows several of the canines' stories in-depth and gives the viewer a feel for the great work done at Best Friends. It also allows viewers to see the special area which houses "red zone" dogs- those who cannot get along with other dogs or people- an area where very few are allowed to visit. While the documentary primarily focuses on the the stories of the dogs, some of the people who work at the ranch are featured as well.
While not every story has a happy ending, this is definitely a documentary worth watching. Any dog lover, or animal lover for that matter, will enjoy watching the progress of the animals and finding out about Best Friends. It is also heartwarming to see the number of people dedicated to helping these animals live the best lives they can.

entry.title: The Proposal
entry.content:
It was chick flick night at the house and my wife gave me a choice of Lake House or The Proposal. Since both starred Sandra Bullock I chose the newer title. It wasnt a bad choice and I have to admit Im a little bit of a sucker for a well written chick flick; even when I do know how it is going to end.


The proposal features Sandra Bullock as Margaret Tate, a retentive and controlling editor at a publishing firm and Ryan Reynolds as her hard working assistant Andrew Paxton. How hard does he work? Think Anne Hathaway in The Devil Wears Prada. Yes, Sandras character is just as demanding as Meryl Streep was in Prada. Margarets problem is that she is Canadian and her visa has been denied. She is about to be deported. Her job is at stake. At the moment she is informed of this development, Andrew walks in and she announces their engagement. A confused Andrew goes along with her ruse; if her job is at stake, so is his. Problem solvedexcept they most prove to the Immigration Department that they are not getting married just to save her job. Off they go to meet Andrew's family and learn enough about each other to fool Immigration.

You know the outcome before you start the movie and I wont pretend that there is ever a time that you think the result will change. The fun is in the voyage. Andrews family is quirky, funny and a few other expected things. There is the mandatory old flame just to make the story a little more interesting, and finally Betty White. White plays Andrews grandmother and she still has it in her to just about steal every scene she is in. I have to admit that I liked this movie. There is something here for almost everyone. There is a scene specifically aimed at pleasing the men who are watching this with their significant other. Interestingly enough the same scene is aimed at women. I said there was something for everyone.


My final Word: The Proposal is a chic flic among chic flics, one that your date wont mind sitting through. You will never doubt how it will turn out, but you will enjoy the trip.

entry.title: a Song that was a Hit before Your Mother was Born
entry.content:
To experience the popular music of different historical epochs is a form of time-travel. Whenever someone wants to evoke a certain period in history in films, the images are almost always coupled with the popular musical form of that era. If one wants to summon up a sense of the turn of the twentieth century the best way is to play some ragtime. The 1920s roared with Dixieland and Chicago style jazz, the 30s sobered up a little with Bing Crosby and the Carter Family and Benny Goodman; the Dorseys and Glenn Miller were swingin the 1940s. But this sort of musical time-travel has only been available to us for a little over 100 years.

Late in the year 1877, Thomas Edison recited the nursery rhyme, Mary had a Little Lamb into his recently constructed Talking Machine and recorded sound was born. Unfortunately for Edison he developed the machine to take dictation and some other business applications and did not see the potential for entertainment his invention held.

Disc recording and reproduction technology was developed a short time later and by the turn of the 20th century the music recording industry was in full swing. The first records were by some of the great orchestras and opera singers of the day. And sentimental ballads sung by Irish tenors such as John McCormack were extremely popular, as well as ragtime music. The year 1917 was to turn all of this upside down.

Within a thirty day span it can be said that ragtime music was not dead, but it was on its last legs and recorded jazz had just been born. March 7th, 1917 marked the release of Livery Stable Blues by the Original Dixieland Jazz Band. And on April 1st, 1917, Scott Joplin died. It is the birth of jazz that I want to focus on in this particular entry.

Livery Stable Blues (which isnt really a blues) was wildly successful and ushered in what was to be called the jazz age of the 1920s. What a lot of people dont realize is that the jazz of the 1920s had the same effect on young people that rock and roll has had on current generations. For a firsthand account of this phenomenon I recommend the book Stardust Road by Bloomingtons own Hoagy Carmichael. He opens the book with his memories of 1924 and his friend Bix Beiderbecke.

Hoagy Carmichael's Dance Band, Indiana University 1924

Bix was the quintessential jazz man of the epoch. He played a hot, sweet cornet, lived fast, drank too much bathtub gin and died young. His band, the Wolverine Orchestra was an octet of young musicians inspired by the Original Dixieland Jass Band, the New Orleans Rhythm Kings and Louis Armstrong. They toured the Midwest playing college campuses, the speakeasies of Chicago and recording at Genett Studios in Richmond, IN. Their music remains an accessible and enjoyable window on the world of our grandparents and great grandparents. For a peek through this musical window in time check out these CDs:
Bix Beiderbecke, Vol.1, Singin the Blues
Bix Beiderbecke, Vol.2, At the Jazz Band Ball
Bix Beiderbecke: Great Original Performances 1924-1930
Complete Original Dixieland Jazz Band
Sometimes I Wonder by Hoagy Carmichael

entry.title: Drag Me to Hell
entry.content:
I always look forward to new horror movies, and this one, just in time for Halloween, didn't disappoint. The film stars Alison Lohman and Justin Long as a pleasant young couple starting their careers and their life together. Christine (Lohman) works in a bank and is trying to be promoted to assistant manager. She faces stiff competition from a slimy co-worker and a boss who thinks she can't make tough decisions. When an old woman comes to her begging for an extension on her mortgage, Christine denies her to prove to her boss she is capable of handling difficult situations. Little does she know the old woman is a gypsy who curses her. Things quickly go from bad to worse as Christine is attacked by the woman who snatches a button from her coat, which Christine later finds. As strange things begin happening to her Christine seeks out the old woman, only to find she has died. In desperation she seeks the help of a fortune teller, who explains she is being haunted by a Lamia, a spirit that will torment her for three days before dragging her to hell. The key is that button, owned by Christine and taken by the gypsy. To break the curse Christine must make the button the property of someone else.

Drag me to Hell offers some real scares and creepy moments. Director Sam Raimi (Spiderman, Evil Dead) brings some fun to the horror genre, keeping the tone just campy enough to be funny but horrific enough to keep tension and fear in the mix. Lohman plays her part as Christine well, while Long is bit dry, although his part is relatively minor. This fun, scary flick is a good choice to get you in the mood for Halloween.

entry.title: Cirque du Soleil "Love" Soundtrack
entry.content: With the release of the latest re-mastered Beatles CDs and the video game Rock Band The Beatles, I thought it might be a good time to look again at Cirque du Soleils Soundtrack to Love. Love, one could say, is the first new Beatles album to come out since the group broke-up. Strictly speaking there is nothing really new on the CD. However, most of the arrangements are different than any you have heard before. George Martin and son had access to everything the Beatles recorded in creating this circus celebration of Beatles music. I dont mean simply all of the songs, but also the mistakes, random conversations, rough takes and more. If it was recorded while trying to make a Beatles song it was fair game in making the Sound Track to Love. The purpose of the music was not to duplicate the Beatles music but to turn it into something that was a tribute to them while at the same time fitting their sound to the unusual circus style of Cirque du Soleil. The result is an entertaining and different look at the Beatles music. One piece features the drums from Tomorrow Never Knows layered on the George Harrison song Within Without You. My personal opinion is that this mash-up works better than either of the original versions does alone. Even Gnik Nus, Sun King played backwards has a surprising charm. In all, this is a new look at a classic band and one that I am sure will please any Beatles fan who is not a diehard purist.

entry.title: X-Men Origins: Wolverine
entry.content:
I will admit that I started this movie with some trepidation as most of the reviews I had read were mediocre at best and added to this is the fact that I have not been a fan of the X-Men comics. Perhaps this helped because I didnt have any preconceived idea of what the story should be. I found myself sitting back and enjoying the story and the special effects. I had a great time with this movie. I thought the story was good, with a lot of twists and turns and enough humor to let me know they werent taking the story too seriously.

X-Men Origins: Wolverines story is summed up in the title. And I wont elaborate beyond this except that the background explains much about the character's actions in the earlier movies. I was surprised to find out that Wolverine had a brother who was every bit as beastly as he was, but with an evil edge that eventually makes him Cain to Wolverines Abel, only without the success that Cain had or is it the other way around? You will have to decide for yourself. The special effects are fun and not too over the top. The physics of the movie are of course impossible, but thats what makes it fun. Hugh Jackman and Leiv Schreiber make very believable brothers and I didnt find myself thinking. Man, they dont look at all alike. Only one aspect of the supposed relationship bothered me. Why did one have blades coming through his knuckles and the other have knife-like fingernails? Still this was a small bother for an otherwise fun movie. If you are watching the movie on DVD make sure to check out the special feature with Stan Lee the original creator of the X-Men Comics. Stan is always fun to listen to and really seems to enjoy talking about his love for comics.

My Final Word: X-Men Origins: Wolverine is a fun movie that doesnt take itself too seriously.

entry.title: Rules of the Game
entry.content: Released in 1939 on the eve of World War II, Jean Renoir's classic, The Rules of the Game has for several decades been considered a classic on par with Citizen Kane. The story begins with a young aviator named Andre, who has just flown across the Atlantic, but laments that his lover is not present to congratulate him. The next scene cuts to a pristine and luminous room, obviously occupied by someone from the bourgeoisie, and it stands in stark contrast to the darkened and fog covered airport runway. The occupier of this room is Christine, and she is the lover of Andre, despite being married to Robert de la Chesnaye, who has also taken a lover himself. It is within this world of the amoral aspirations of the bourgeoisie, Renoir chose to set his film and cynically recount the events of a weekend getaway . It was precisely this subject matter which enraged many within France, and even led to the banning of the film for some time. However, it is Renoir's fluid camerawork(i.e. tracking shots), and use of deep focus, which truly enlivens the film. Deep focus is a cinematic technique which places all objects within the frame in focus so as to highlight their importance in relation to each other. In one scene, two characters discuss the integrity and honesty of another character named Octave ,who in the distance enters behind them. While the characters are discussing Octave, and walking towards the camera in the foreground, Octave continues to sneak into the house in the background, only to betray both of the characters in the next scene. The scene presents him both literally, and symbolically, going behind their backs. The film contains several other multi-layered scenes, several of which extend beyond the typical length for the time period, in addition to the memorable dialogue, as well as the editing, which is evident in the famous hunting scene.

entry.title: The Walkmen-You and Me
entry.content: On their fourth album, The Walkmen have crafted an album remarkable in its precision and riveting in its arrangement. You and Me unfolds, layer after layer, with each succeeding listen. The album refuses to immediately seize listeners ears as such previous efforts, Bows and Arrows or A Hundred Miles Off, and instead unfurls gradually drawing you in with each successive listen. Lead singer, Hamilton Leithauser once piercing style and sardonic observations have been reigned in and are far more controlled, while presenting a more nuanced approach to the material. This time around he presents himself as a Roy Orbison filtered through punk rock, who is just as comfortable crooning as he is screaming his declarations. As for his once continuous sarcasm, a more somber and delicate character laments the loss of a love. In the past, everyone has attempted to pigeon-hole The Walkmen by comparing them to such disparate acts as the U2 and even the Velvet Underground. However, such comparisons do not come close to scratching the surface of their musicianship. Their once ragged edges, which consisted of pounding toms, tremulous guitars, and woozy organs, now have tinkling keys, and an all around more restrained approach. This contributes to a sound nostalgic for early 1950's Sun Records rock and roll, with more reverb, but attuned to the uninhibited moments generated by punk rock. While the Walkmen seek to develop this aged atmosphere, they're not afraid to imbue it with the more unhinged moments that were bubbling under the surface of early rock and roll. Overall, that is what makes this album entirely unique when held up to previous efforts. The Walkmen have managed to pull together seemingly polar opposite spectrum's of rock and roll, and combined them in a record that oscillates from raucous to ethereal.

entry.title: Battlestar Galactica
entry.content: It has been over eight years since September 11th, and a multitude of art has attempted to assess the current state of the post-9/11 world. Some have succeeded in providing poignant and arresting examinations of the current circumstances, while others wallow in sentimental reflections and offer succinct resolutions. The one that strays from such contrived elements and stands head and shoulders above the rest, is a science fiction television series with all the conventional trappings of the genre in its basic plot. Where the shows deviates is in its morally ambiguous discussions of terrorism, suicide bombers, investigative committees, the role of the military, and etc... The shows revolves around the Galactica fleet and several other ships who are the only remaining members of the human race. Several years ago, humans developed Cylons; which are machines with artificial intelligence, who eventually turn on their masters and rebel. After coming to a peaceful resolution, the Cylons sequester themselves in a remote part of the universe. Decades later they return and decimate the twelve colonies occupied by human beings with nuclear weapons. Now commander Adama and President Laura Roslin, must lead the Galactica and several ships to a world where they can begin a new life removed from the Cylons. From the beginning the shows ambition and influences are conspicuous. The opening scene contains a character jogging around the Galactica, strikingly similar to the introduction of Dave in 2001: A Space Odyssey. One character is even named Starbuck, just like one of the myriad characters in Herman Melville's epic masterpiece Moby Dick. From here, the viewer understands the serious aspirations of the shows creator, which does present elements of action and suspense, but they are minimal at best. Instead of providing of heroic scenes involving the rescue of innocent civilians, the show examines the moral predicament and eventual guilt of characters, who allow the civilians to die, to save thousands of others from possible death. In the first few episodes alone, the shows tackles a suicide bombing, terrorism as a result of occupation, and the role of the military in relation to the government. Meanwhile there are no clear cut resolutions, and characters who continually make detrimental decisions, are often the most sympathetic. What Battlestar Galactica achieves is in artfully creating characters and a world with no simple good and evil dichotomy or succinct moral resolutions. People in the government and military continually make decisions riddled with compromising facets, and in the meantime, a terrorist presents legitimate concerns about the democracy of the current administration. Often we desire simple and pat resolutions which simply confirm ideologies we already believe to be true. Instead of confirming the ideals of a political voice, Battlestar Galactica takes a world decimated by tragedy and examines the struggle to formalize a society in the wake of such a tragedy. Still there are no obvious parallels with our world, but it does present story lines which resonate with the current political climate. In the end, it forces the viewer to examine the issues on their own and contemplate the grey areas of an increasingly intricate world.

entry.title: Dirty Projectors
entry.content: The Dirty Projectors have produced their most accessible and mellifluous album, and as a result have obtained exposure on both ABC and NPR. The group is the brain child of Dave Longstreth, who after dropping out of Yale, developed his material with the help of friends over a period of years. After releasing several highly conceptual and cerebral albums, which leaned heavily on orchestration and avant garde elements, the Dirty Projectors released 2007's Rise Above. The album was conceived by Longstreth as a reinterpretation of Black Flag's Damaged, but instead of guttural hardcore punk, Longstreth only played what he could remember from the album and inserted knotty melodies and heavy falsetto. With Bitte Orca, Longstreth continues the intricate guitar elements and allows his dueling muses(Amber Coffman and Angel Deradoorian) to cultivate some mesmerizing harmonies. The first single, Stillness is the New Move, consists entirely of Coffman belting out Beyone level declarations of affection over pulsating drums and a lubricious melody. Throughout the album, Longstreth acquiesces control to his female counterparts, but when they intercept each other, and weave back and forth on the track Remade Horizon, Longstreth's talent as an arranger shines through. Other stellar points include Useful Chamber, which opens with a pulsating synth line and builds slowly before descending into dueling virtuoso guitar solos and the towering harmonies of Deradoorian and Coffman. So if you're willing to take the plunge, Bitte Orca provides some truly mesmerizing feats of vocal arrangements and intricate guitar work. It is a perfectly accessible amalgamation of the avant garde and r/b, and is delivered with an infectious pop bravado.

entry.title: Inkheart
entry.content:
Inkheart was not the movie I expected. I felt a slight disappointment about this, but the disappointment was greatly outweighed by my enjoyment of totally different movie. Inkheart stars Brendan Frazer as Mo Folchart a silvertongue. Being a silvertongue means that he must be careful about what he reads aloud, because it becomes real. The catch is that if he pulls a character out of a book, someone nearby becomes part of the book.
Mo didnt always know he was a silvertongue. He found out the hard way when he brought out some of the more villainous characters out of a book by reading it aloud to his family. The trailers made this movie look like a comedy, and while there is a little comedy in the movie it is primarily a fantasy adventure with a little mystery thrown in as well. I was also expecting the buffoon adventurer that Brendan Frazer plays so well. But this character was not there either. He plays a simple father who cares and loves his family and is forced by circumstances to come to grips with the evil he has accidentally brought into the world.
Perhaps this is why Inkheart did not do as well as expected in the theaters, people came expecting a comedy action adventure and instead found themselves watching an adventure with heart. I had trouble at first with the movie myself because I kept waiting for Brendan Frazer to bewell, Brendan Frazer. Once I got past that, I settled down to enjoy the story. I plan to watch this movie again. I think I will enjoy it more the second and third time around.
My Final Word: This movie is not your typical Brendan Frazer film. If you are expecting a comedy, it has its moments, but you will enjoy it more as a story about a family caught up in very unusual circumstances.

entry.title: Frozen River
entry.content: While definitely not an uplifting film, this movie tells an interesting story and features a great perfomance by the underrated Melissa Leo. She plays a mother of two boys whose gambling addicted husband has gone missing. Her dream is to pay off the double-wide she has been trying to purchase, but her husband keeps disappearing with the money. Through a series of accidents she joins forces with Lila, a desperate Mohawk woman, and begins transporting illegal aliens across the frozen Hudson River. Both women face limited employment prospects and have few choices to make the kind of money they need to survive, let alone thrive. It's a no win situation presenting many suspenseful moments throughout the film. Just one glimpse of Leo's face gives incredible insight into the weariness and fear of her character. The supporting cast is very good also, especially Charlie McDermott, the actor who plays the oldest son. He excellently portrays the anger and frustration a teenager would feel in his situation

entry.title: In Praise of Black and White
entry.content:
I still remember when I first saw Sammy Terry, WTTVs Ghoul host for their late night horror movies. I use to cringe as I watched the movies that he hosted. I would empty out the cabinet in the family room and squeeze myself inside so that I could watch the films without the monsters on the screen seeing me.

Then the unthinkable happened. We bought a color TV and the world changed. Sammy Terry was no longer the lovable ghoul I loved so much. He was a man with a bad make-up job and fake rubber hands that looked as if they had been made from those yellow rubber gloves you use to wash dishes. The movies he showed no longer seemed as dark and ominous. The blood seemed almost cheering. The scenes were lit with bright lights to show off the color which had the effect of making them look more like TV sitcoms than dark stories of terror. The horror had lost its horror in wash of color.

We take color for granted now. But prior to 1950, black and white was king. Color can get in the way of the story. If you place the wrong color on the screen you can distract your viewer to the wrong part of the screen. The wrong color can change your view of a character. I remember watching The Lone Ranger; his white suite and silver bullets where a symbol of his fight for good, justice and purity. Then came color and I discovered that his suite was not white, nor even a buck-skin yellow, but powder blue. Powder blue! What was that about?

Then there was Superman, strange visitor from another planet. I knew from the comics that his suit was blue and red; that his big S was set on a background of yellow. In black and white it looked great. It was easy to imagine the suite in the glorious color of the comic books. When the show switched to color after season two the vividness was gone, the colors faded. The contrast between the faded blue tights and the dark red shorts was gone. It lacked the luster that it needed. How could the amazing suit from the first two seasons have turned out to be so drab in color? The answer was black and white. When you film in black and white you dont have to be concerned about what color a thing really is, just how it appears in the final product. During the first two seasons, Supermans suit was really shades of brown. It photographed better, when they switched to color, it had to really be a outfit of blue and red and it ended up looking like a ill fitting pair of pajamas.

Horror and mysteries is where black and white really shows its stuff. You can set a mood in black and white that is hard to reproduce in color. One of the greatest films ever made was Casablanca. The ending shot with Rick and Captain Renault walking away together into the fog covered darkness would have been almost impossible to film in color. Color would have shown all of the flaws in the face of Frankensteins monster. Draculas face would have gone from looking pale and bloodless to looking white like a Geisha. Black and white can make even a bright day seem dark and ominous.

Color also brought about an increased interest in special effects. There is nothing so much fun to watch as a car that blows up in a cloud of smoke and red and yellow fire. Of course cars dont really blow up like that, but it is an awe inspiring sight. The limitations of black and white filmed forced the focus of a film on the story, rather than the action. If you want to see what I mean by this, try turning off the color on an action film like Rambo, or the Transformers. They are not nearly so much fun to watch in black and white and the lameness of the story is much more apparent.

We lost a lot in the switch from black and white to color. We are more likely to settle for a movie with a weak plot and lots of action rather than a strong story line. Im not saying that there are no great color films, nor am I saying that there are not any bad black and white films. However, color has made it a lot harder to tell the good films from the bad for many of us. If you want to see some truly great films watch some of the old black and white classics. I think you will be surprised at just how great these movies are.
